comments_data.body: I wonder do we need some sanitization here? It's probably a low chance there being some personal data considering that would be high cardinality but still, it may be worth checking if we have something in place somewhere in the pipeline or if this is non-issue.

That's a good point! I don't think we really care about the tag values themselves, which may contain sensitive data, but it could be nice to know which operators and which tags (name, http.status_code, etc.) are used more often. I'll filter the `label` content to only allow values for certain types of suggestions so we avoid this potential issue.

comments_data.body:
I think it's best to just use a fixed number here to determine how many we want to fit in the modal. 

If `DEFAULT_PER_PAGE_PAGINATION` increases to some larger value it might affect the scrolling of the modal content. Inversely if it becomes smaller you might not have many items to view. And I'm not sure what happens if `DEFAULT_PER_PAGE_PAGINATION / 4` is a float / fractal 😅

commits_data.message: Loki: Add multitenancy support for the HTTP client
Loki: Support to push with multitenancy mode

comments_data.body: I'd recommend switching this around, making the default behavior requiring TLS.

Do we need all the guards here?
If we do, I believe this could be expressed more left-aligned like this?

```suggestion
	orgIDs := md[lowerOrgIDHeaderName]
	switch len(orgIDs) {
	case 0:
		md = md.Copy()
		md[lowerOrgIDHeaderName] = []string{tenantID}
		newCtx = metadata.NewOutgoingContext(ctx, md)
	case 1:
		if orgIDs[0] != tenantID {
			return ctx, ErrDifferentOrgIDPresent
		}
	default:
		return ctx, ErrTooManyOrgIDs
	}
```

Honestly, I just copy-pasted from here:
https://github.com/weaveworks/common/blob/master/user/grpc.go#L25
_(for the sake of not adding a new -direct- dependency for just few lines)_

But also wondered about its need... 
I'd say currently isn't needed at all, but thought that it could be useful in the future to prevent unexpected situations hard to debug (I guess the purpose of these checks).

However, I'm happy with either applying your suggestions or keeping it simpler for now (I'd probably prefer this for simplicity if that makes sense as well haha).

Thanks! 🙏🏻
Choose you, I'm ok with both, I don't see why this could be a problem with the subset we're using 🤔
Okay, let's get rid of this until actually needed. Thanks!

title: Logs volume: Refactor

commits_data.message: Rename log volume in redux to supp query to make it more generic
Remove suppQueryData && suppQueryData.data[0] check as it is redundant

comments_data.body: This was added because we need a utility function that checks if string is enum in `for (const string of Object.keys(enum))` to satisfy typescript. And currently (in typescript 4.8), we need `as` assertion.  We can refactor when we update to ts 4.9.

I think I see the reasoning behind this, but the more I look at it the less I think is a good approach. Here, you're reading keys from `SuppQueryType` only to check `Object.values(SuppQueryType).includes(type as SuppQueryType);` again, which it obviously is. I'll try to come up with an alternative implementation.

> unnecessary dynamic programming

I think the purpose of this is to be dynamic, as `LogsVolume` won't be the only one. However I also don't think the hardcoded object in line 54 is optimal and should be dynamic.

> which is a object with key that is type of supp query

What is a "supp query"? I'd like to know if I'm missing context or maybe we should come up with a different name.

Even if dynamic, at some point we would need to specify/harcode all possible keys (siblings of `LogsVolume`). If we just need to do what `loadSuppQueries()` is doing in this PR, my advice would be to use the simplest implementation.

If we need to do extra work, or iterate over the keys again, I would think about adding an array of keys to use in the iteration (e.g. `const sup_query_types [ 'LogsVolume', '', ... ]`, and avoid doing `object.keys()` or `object.values()` to an enum. At least I don't find the produced code to be pleasant.

Good point. I was trying to come up with good naming, but had hard time. So all suggestions are more than welcome! 🙂 First I was thinking `supporting`, then `supplementary`, but these are quite long. But maybe better long than vague. I was also thinking `additional`, but it sounds vague as well. 🤔

Yeah, I was thinking about unifying  values of `suppQueryType.LogsVolume` and `SETTINGS_KEYS.enableVolumeHistogram` so it would be same and this would be removed. But as is this refactor, I didn't want to change it here.  What are your thoughts about this?
If `supporting` correctly describes the types of queries, I would just use the full word to avoid this ambiguity.
Nice idea! I like it. Looks much more simple. Let me try it out. 🙂
Could we move this to `public/app/types/explore.ts` as well?
They are not quite meta information, but what about `metaQueries`?

I think it does, but I'd like to hear what other people think. Basically it is a query that is optionaly (at user's request) run in explore in addition to original query. Such as when you run log query and want to see log histogram. Or when you run metrics query and want to see log samples. I like the `supplementary` the most, but it is veeery long.
Absolutely! Good point.
In that case, both `meta` and `supplementary` seem like good candidates 👍
`suppQueryData && suppQueryData.data[0]` shouldn't be necessary anymore here.
Sounds good to me to change it as well.
This was removed in https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/60998/commits/2c7b92ea0ec7a9f14049161befe6ad5ca8824f53 by using `const type of SUPPORTING_QUERY_TYPES`

Updated to  https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/60998/commits/2c7b92ea0ec7a9f14049161befe6ad5ca8824f53 to use `const type of SUPPORTING_QUERY_TYPES`. Moreover, I have added comment to `supportingQuerySettings` that goal is to remove it and use the same values for settings and for enum.
As mentioned updated to https://github.com/grafana/grafana/commit/2c7b92ea0ec7a9f14049161befe6ad5ca8824f53 to use const type of SUPPORTING_QUERY_TYPES.

As we use `meta` to name meta information from query, plus in Loki we use `metadataRequest` to get resources, I have decided to use `supplementary` to make it more distinguished in https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/60998/commits/a2940be22d2b828d555a81a37a30dcab12aa3732 and https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/60998/commits/162af478436d7a8d2232a0f9270ddb91f19f1f1e
Oh, I did a mistake and renamed it to `supporting` instead of `supplementary`. Working on fix now.
Fixed in https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/60998/commits/ccfb7a63a40d6b6649cb14463b07edc4f91b5226
It is, because suppQueryData can be  `DataQueryResponse | undefined`.
Moved in https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/60998/commits/42ec50154bf1fe7d3343b448492f311e270efdb5
Yep, but you already check for that in line 644: `if (suppQueryData && suppQueryData.data[0]) {`
Oh yes, you are correct. Removed in https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/60998/commits/f5cbc2d1952892f96e0e147325ac365a745ff529
`SuppQuery` -> `SupplementaryQuery`

```
|----------|---------------------|
```

title: Alerting: Support customizable timeout for screenshots

commits_data.message:
Alerting: Support customizable timeout for screenshots

This commit adds a customizable timeout for screenshots called
capture_timeout. The default value is 10 seconds, and the maximum
value is 30 seconds. This timeout should be less than the minimum
Interval of all Evaluation Groups to avoid back pressure on alert
rule evaluation.

comments_data.body:
I think `?` is not needed here. Also in other places.

```suggestion
    expect(query.datasource.uid).toBe('ds1');
```

Hmm... `featureToggles` is an object not a function. Shouldn't it be:

```suggestion
    featureToggles: useFeatToggles,
```
There's a lot of code duplication in the setup. Could it be extracted to a helper function for readability?

I'm not sure if it's mocked properly. This code will have no effect in the tested code as `featureToggles` is mocked as a function that is never executed. So the code that is using the toggle always returns `undefined` (trying to read the property of a function definition / not its results) for `config.featureToggles.exploreMixedDatasource`:
According to TypeScript it is needed. If I removed it I'd get an error:
That's what I thought as well and then got the following error when running the test: This one relates to [the one below](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/60977#discussion_r1085399412).

These tests were all added in the same describe block as tests around the reducer, even though I wouldn't consider these testing logic in the reducer. 

Like for the first test, it's dispatching an action and testing that the state was affected accordingly, that's logic that is in the reducer. For tests like this one that call `addQueryRow` and test that logic, I think it would make sense to make another describe block. I think that helps structure this test file for future growth, what do you think?
Absolutely makes sense.
Done.

The test data in single tests and `config.featureToggles.exploreMixedDatasource` weren't mocked properly.
I think I fixed both issues now.
I don't get your point yet. `config.featureToggles.exploreMixedDatasource` is set in `beforeEach()` and when running the test in debug mode it works like expected (see below).
I removed `__esModule: true` and added a `afterEach()`. in order to complete it and it still works.
Not sure if that's a real case scenario (it's not possible to have two different data sources without the root being a mixed data source) so probably can be removed.
It's `postgres` because it's a default data source, right? If yes, might be worth adding a comment to make it clear.
`datasourceOverride` is internal implementation detail, I'd rather call it "with mixed data source".
It's true that the scenario can't set in the UI. Since I am not testing behaviour in the UI but the sole function I would like to keep it and I added a comment in the test description.

Kindsys: Replace `DefForGen` with `kindsys.Kind` (#62642)

* Kindsys: Replace DeclForGen with kindsys.Kind

DeclForGen was always unnecessary - it just wasn't obvious on initial
implementation, when we were focused on generating unique types for each
core kind. This removes it, considerably simplifying interactions with
kindsys - virtually everything now just relies on kindsys.Kind and its
derived interfaces.

* Removed unused jenny

* Rename params in jennies

comments_data.body: What happens if you try to access explore with a compact URL and the feature flag is false?

I wonder if wed like to put an error message in the console or logs for this. With a message maybe like "A link to explore using a deprecated format was attempted, but there is a feature flag that disallows access. If access is critical, please add "legacyExploreCompactURL" to your config, but be warned we will be removing the feature flag and disabling access entirely at a later version. Please change the source of these URLs to prevent loss of functionality" and then maybe log it. I'm thinking for the use case for someone who has somehow missed the warnings prior to this and hits the limitation from the feature flag for the first time.

I'm not saying this is critical but wondering if some communication would be useful for this step.

then i'd rather show the warning similarly to what we currently have, but with the content you proposed. console errors are pretty obscure to 90% of non-devs (and undiscoverable, one should know an error happened to look for a console message, and there will be no indication of that in the UI).

happy to do that if we want to surface it 👍

comments_data.body: super nitpicky but I think it's our general style to put this sort of thing after imports

not really related to this pr, but i think sometimes it helps to update these test names to describe under what circumstances we expect these things to happen, or to describe the user's state.

So for example:
- it should disable access key id field when the datasource has been previously configured vs it should enable access key id field when the datasource has not been saved
or 
- it should handle previously saved datasources
I'm curious why all these waitfors had to be added and why they weren't necessary before
maybe add a test for expanding beyond the first 2 default log groups?
might be nice to update this logGroups to differentiate it from the logGroups above like `updatedLogGroups` or something
are we handling defaults now? Maybe we can remove this comment?
seems sort of a shame we can't do this all in one go rather than hitting the api multiple times right? idk maybe it doesn't really matter?
this test isn't much but it feels a bit odd to delete the test file when we are keeping the file right?

this code feels a bit off to me. If we haven't saved or we've saved only once then save? And then fetch it again asynchronously below which may or may not finish before this save?

do we need to save to the backend? Is it not enough to update it locally in state? I think I misunderstanding why we need anything here.

Also I think regardless we should probably add more tests for this so it's clear what's happening.
Yes don't know what happened here. Fixed now!
Yeah I agree. Updated some of the test descriptions.

I don't know - there's no batch api support for this in AWS, so this needs to happen somewhere on our side. This endpoint is used in other places in our code base, so I think this is the best solution.

This test didn't do much - defaults are now defined in the [datasource](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/main/public/app/plugins/datasource/cloudwatch/datasource.ts#L180-L185) file and applied by the framework, so testing this cannot be done within the scope of the plugin. It would require an e2e test of something to verify this. 

Aside from removing this test, this PR doesn't change things in the LogQueryField so don't know what tests can be added here. Think it's better to remove the test file than keeping an empty file. WDYT?

It because now there are async actions going on in the component (loading the data source). It we didn't add `waitFor`,, jest would make assertions before async actions were completed leading to falsy tests.
Yes! Comment removed and prop signature changed.

This ConfigEditor needs to make async backend calls to load for example log groups. If the data source wasn't saved before, it needs to save it otherwise there's no backend to call. 

But I agree, the code was pretty horrible. Have done some refactoring and also written a few tests. Hopefully better now.
maybe not that related to the rest of the work in this PR, but wanted to mike first column wider so that there's room to display the full log group name.
just verifying there's no chance that a user could have the frontend cached in their browser somehow and make a request to /log-groups when the server endpoint doesn't exist, right?

I feel like we should be waiting for something to load rather than waiting for something not to have been called right? Like maybe we await a waitFor sign that the original async call has finished and then do the expect checks outside of the waitFor. I could be misunderstanding but here it feels like it will waitFor things not to have been called (which I would expect to happen immediately?) and could give a false positive test pass right?

I'm not sure if this is related to the useDatasource changes here, but I found a weird bug in manually testing:

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6620164/210586268-ee375ca6-97c2-4be2-86a0-8e870a14cb62.mov

We've run into this stuff before where a user is putting in some information in the connection config settings, and those unsaved changes need to be saved before we can fetch log groups.

It gets very complicated very quickly. I wonder if we should instead add a save button that is like "load log groups" or when you click on the modal we save any connection details and then fetch the log groups.
are we using this provider/store? Sorry I think I missed where that happens!

Yeah, I was originally having it sneakily autosave when the selector was opened before (line 118) with the `saved` bool to determine if it needed to be re-saved. I don't think we should necessarily be sneaky about it, but we do need to save before we load the log groups.
optional: I feel like the `NO_OF` is unnecessary? same for the parameter below.
optional: can the access key tests be next to each other?
As note about the issue that sarah mentioned with getting old log groups after the credentials are changed, if we decide to sneakily save to fix it we should add a test for that.
No I don't think so

I think it's the opposite way around - if you assert that something has **not** happened immediately after first render and before all async action have completed, you might receive a false positive because the "thing" happened at the very end of the scenario. 

https://testing-library.com/docs/dom-testing-library/api-async/#waitfor
No that's true, not necessary for this scenario. Removed it

I'm not suggesting we wait for first render, I'm suggesting we waitFor some sign the component has finished loading, not just started loading. But anyway I don't think this test is so relevant anymore anyway!

commits_data.message:
API: Correctly use new grafana_com.api_url setting in /api/gnet proxy

During the review of the initial PR adding this (#59506) I removed
a new global variable from the setting package, but forgot to update
the reference to the new setting, so the API URL wasn't actually
being used. This PR updates the proxy endpoint to use the API
URL correctly.

Aside: I'm not a huge fan of how the error is being ignored when parsing
the URL, but I think that should be addressed in a separate PR if anyone
has a suggestion for how we should handle it. (Should we check that the
URL is valid when parsing config?)

title: Scene: PanelTimeRange

comments_data.body: We would need a nice way to reuse more here from SceneTimeRange
this should over time be replaced by a full time picker (so when you click it it opens a modal to specify time range for panel)

I like this idea! But I think it would require more changes than just the localized time range. I.e. given the Query runner is attached to the root of the scene, we have to add a mechanism that will identify which panel requested a query with overridden range, so that other panels that consume the data via `sceneGraph.getData()` won't get updates.

I'm thinking more of future use cases. I.e. Two panels sharing the same query runner when comparing data from different ranges. Would probably be nice to have a single source of queries and only the execution context changes. But - we may leave that problem for now since it will work with multiple SceneQueryRunners.

title: Alerting: Fix handling of special floating-point cases when writing observed values to annotations

commits_data.message: Fix json serialization of state values
Don't return error if we fail to look up dashboard, just log it and move on

comments_data.body: Should we also return this error to the caller?
same with these, do we want to fail silent from the perspective of the caller? How do we also test this?
Does this mean the values can now be a combination of strings and floats?

No, this was intentional,
1. This function is the entry point to a goroutine, even if it returned an error it'd be ignored
2. Since annotations are an auxiliary thing, we don't want errors to bubble up the stack. This is a case of "if it fails, log it and move on."

Yes, that's the intended behavior.

Also, I think git got a little confused on the diff here. This code was simply moved to be higher in the file, not changed. It's nothing new, you can see it exactly matches the code that got removed from line 97 in the old version. It doesn't really have anything to do with the substance of the PR, I was just vertically organizing the code within the file.

Yes, only inside the annotation, not inside anything important like state.
Annotations support arbitrary types here (it just gets rendered wholesale in the UI). I felt this was a much better UX than just dropping the unrepresentable key.
I wonder if we can embed EvalString instead? We can parse it on read when it is needed.. Just an idea
I wonder if it should be followed by `return` so we do not log debug in error case
I think we should not even `return` but continue with empty dashboard and panel IDs because otherwise we will break state history

Sure, but this is completely orthogonal to this PR. I doubt this is the only issue we have of this nature, this code was simply moved inside the file and not touched.

I think we should do that in a separate PR, I'd rather not lump it in here, because it deserves its own tests just for that case.
Good idea, I used a slightly different pattern in the Loki implementation that removes ambiguity and prevents this whole class of issue. I'll fix it here and PR it as well.
What about always rendering the number as a string instead of switching on the value?

I looked into parse-on-read, unfortunately it's a very large amount of code churn. The annotations service has simplejson deeply baked into its API, and it relies on serialization to happen at the ORM level. It would be a pretty deep change - changing the annotation service's models in a fundamental way.

The UI is looking for a specific thing inside the annotation, unfortunately. I didn't want to fall back all the time, only when necessary, as the annotation seems to prefer numbers. It displays a little nicer, no quotes, etc and IMO is more what users expect.
This was done implicitly in a different PR, this diff is no longer part of this PR.

title: Cloudwatch: Add support for template variables in new log group picker

commits_data.message: add support for variables in log group picker
move migration stuff back to component and also change scenario name
add comment for why we use uniq
return empty array in case no result
support variables log group variable when loading log group fields

comments_data.body: Lots of state and stuff here so would be good to split this component eventually :sweat_smile:

Some context for the changes in this file. Before we started the work to move resource requests to the new layered architecture, CloudWatch logs did not use the CallResource api. All requests - `StartQuery`, `GetQueryResult`, `StopQuery`, `DescribeLogGroups`, `DescribeAllLogGroups`,  `GetLogGroupFields`, `GetLogEvents` - went through the DataQuery api. Using the DataQuery api for discovery data is bad practice and it also made it hard to structure code both in backend and in the frontend. After this pr, the only discovery data request that still goes through the DataQuery  api is the GetLogEvents request, but hopefully that can be removed too soon. 

Previously, all the requests went through the `makeLogActionRequest` method. The calling method was passing the `makeReplacement` boolean arg, and if it was set to true, some(?) of the props passed would be replaced as template variables. This was very un-intuitive, so main goal here is to interpolate variables where the query is actually created so that it becomes easier to test and read the code.
Now none of the calling methods wants to skip cache, so I removed this argument.

This func is pretty similar to the already existing [expandVariableToArray](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/main/public/app/plugins/datasource/cloudwatch/query-runner/CloudWatchRequest.ts#L59), but I didn't want to use it because it 
* only takes a single string
* converts the input string to an array, even though the input string was not a variable. this feels like undesired behavior. 

We should probably use this new func rather than expandVariableToArray in other places too, but I don't know exactly what that would entail. Definitively out of scope for this PR.
I don't think you need this variable, you can set input.NextToken directly at the end of the loop
This should also return a `NextToken` to make sure that it's respecting the field and not the token
this can be combined into the next line
should this just be called log-groups to be more restful? I guess we could do that in a future pr or something
should we send along a boolean instead of a string?
Does this test description match the test? It seems a bit confusing to me what it's removing variables from? From the query?
Is a "startQueryRequest" like a long running query request?
hmm, maybe we can set up sometime tomorrow to talk more about this, I think it sounds important and I'm missing (or forgot 😓) some of this context
can you talk more about these changes? Why do we have to add query string and refId? and why can we remove this skipCache/makeReplacements thing?
what did this do before?
Why did they want to skip the cache before and why do they not now?
I guess this is old but what's "GetLogEventsRequest"?
Why do we have both req.ListAllLogGroups and a req.Limit?
are these uniqs necessary?
To add on, it's not clear to me why we want to do this?
Yeah, cloudwatch logs does a weird thing where it handles the async stuff on the frontend, but it makes calls to the backend to start the query and such.
I do sort of understand why the variables don't count toward this, but also I feel like it may be confusing from a user perspective if their variable maps to a log group and isn't counted?
Yes good idea!

Similar to the long running query feature in Athena and Redshift, CW logs polls the grafana backend (and the logs apis) to check if there are results to fetch. Unlike the Athena and Redshift apis, the logs api can also return partial responses. This is neat because even though the query may need to scan petabytes of data which can take minutes, you may be able to see some result on the logs panel after only a few seconds. However, if we cache a partial response, it will mess up query caching pretty badly. For that reason, none of query data requests (StartQuery, GetQueryResult, StopQuery) should be cached. Some of the requests that have now been moved to the resource request flow (through api.ts) used to set the `skipCache` parameter to false, but now that they're not using the `makeLogActionRequest` anymore, we can safely remove the argument from this function since all the calling methods always wants the cache to be bypassed. 

Let's talk more about this in the mob session!
I agree! Should be changed now.
These are url parameters, so we can only send strings.

Oh yes this was confusing! I've updated the scenario name and also added a comment in the component. Hopefully that makes things clearer. 

If a template variable is defined in the legacy logs query like this:
``` typescript
const logsQuery: CloudWatchLogsQuery = {
    ...,
    logGroupNames: ['logGroup1', '$logGroupVariable'],
  }

```

Then there's no need to call the `getLogGroups` api to substitute the variable value for a log group arn - this will be taken of in the log query execution flow instead. So we just need to make sure any variables are being moved to the new log group array. So for the above query, expected output would be:
``` typescript
const logsQuery: CloudWatchLogsQuery = {
    ...,
    logGroupNames: undefined,
    logGroups: [{ arn: 'arn', name: 'loggroupname' }, { arn: '$logGroupVariable', name: '$logGroupVariable' }],
  }
```

That's a good question, and also the main driver behind this refactoring! 
As said before, all different query subTypes called this method. Some of these sub types wanted their query props to be replaced as variablas. If so, they set the `makeReplacements` arg to true. 

If you look below, what happens is pretty nasty with a deeply nested if statements. The idea here is that variables are supposed to be interpolated before the backend query is issued. For the logs query, it's in the `handleLogQueries` method above. And all the resource requests that used to be in this file are now moved to api.ts ts and that's also where the variables are being interpoalted.

The CloudWatch datasource file implement the [DataSourceWithLogsContextSupport](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/main/packages/grafana-data/src/types/logs.ts#L154) interface. That means the platform (probably logs query runner or logs panel) will call the [getLogRowContext](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/main/public/app/plugins/datasource/cloudwatch/datasource.ts#L137) method in the data source file. I'm not familiar with this method and I don't know when it's being triggered, but it seems like what CloudWatch logs does is that it will fetch log event from the `GetLogEvents` api, tweak the response to the format that DataSourceWithLogsContextSupport expects. 

Since this is not a data query, it should be using the call resource api instead. It's the last subType request that should be moved to the resource api instead. See [this epic](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/issues/57146) or more details.
Limit is the maximum items per page, and if ListAllLogGroups is true we'll iterate over all pages. If false, only the first page.

Yes. Let's say for example this is the logGroupNames array:
```typescript 
['logGroup1', '$logGroupVariable']
```
If $logGroupVariable is a multi-valued variable, and one of it's value is the same as `logGroup1` which is already in the logGroupNames array, the array will include dupes:
```typescript 
// expanded
['logGroup1', 'logGroup1', 'logGroup2']
```
When logGroupNames includes dupes, the  `StartLogQuery` api will return an error. Weirdly, it returns a permission error (?). However, removing dupes with the uniq func solves the problem.

@academo good question! i can think of a couple of reasons:
- keeps the list of props succinct
- i don't think a consumer of `<Alert>` actually wants to configure this. i think they just want the component to do the correct thing, which would be set it correctly based on the `severity` as we do for the icon for example. 

also i've just noticed that `Alert` already extends `HTMLAttributes<HTMLDivElement>` and spreads extra props onto the root div, so this PR isn't necessary. you can already pass both `aria-label` and `role` to the component to override this now. 

having said that, i do think it would be a good change to set this default role based on the `severity`

Aaa, nice, I completely missed that it is extending the `HTMLAttributes<HTMLDivElement>`!

I think what I will do then is that if the role is not defined manually then it will be inferred based on the `severity`!

comments_data.body: Could you explain why this no longer passes? Or are there just outdated references?
Let's remember to drop before merge

We can't drop it - In order to keep the diff minimal, there are now a lot of attributes and functions that remain unused. My next PR shortly after this one will take care of removing this linter skip and delete all the dead code.
This no longer needs a lock as `Base` already has one.

The diff here is ruined because we need to take `Base`'s lock, which causes nesting - there's no functional change here. We just need to make sure that we lock (with the same lock) all the way down to calling `applyConfig` which does not use Base's lock.

The diff here is ruined because we need to take Base's lock, which causes nesting - there's no functional change here. We just need to make sure that we lock (with the same lock) all the way down to calling applyConfig which does not use Base's lock.
Do not conflate `ApplyConfig` with `applyConfig` - this one also needs a lock because all public functions should be safe to be called concurrently.
This diff is somewhat clear but the gist is that everything where we doing is now done by `Base.ApplyConfig` - whatever we need from here - we inject via `AlertingConfiguration`

This test is asserting on the Alertmanager internals. It uses what the Alertmanager calls the "[marker](https://github.com/prometheus/alertmanager/blob/main/types/types.go#L93)" to assert for alerts that have been received but not processed. 

These components are private and are no longer accessible in any form from `grafana/alerting` (as a consumer shouldn't have a need to access them).

The test was ported 1:1 to grafana/alerting in https://github.com/grafana/alerting/blob/main/alerting/grafana_alertmanager_test.go#L34 so I reckon is safe to skip for now. There are several integration tests that asserts this functionality anyway.

We no longer have `ready` as this was originally designed to be an internal non-safe version of `Ready` - this now lives in in `grafana/alerting`.

That aside, there's no reason why this test should rely on `ready` except to make it a tiny bit faster.
Same as https://github.com/grafana/alerting/issues/38 but inverse.
Filed in https://github.com/grafana/alerting/issues/39
No issue as is part of a very large, very obvious effort - don't have a concrete plan yet will create one once I do.
It preserved it well enough to follow. These lock changes seem straightforward :+1:
Do we still need the lock here? there is a gap between `am.Base.Ready()` and `am.Base.GetStatus()`, the config could be concurrently updated there.

Good shout -- it was a bit confusing, so I've removed the `am.Base.Ready()` check.

If you look at `Base.GetStatus` it does hold a lock for getting the status from the configuration - so really all that we need is to execute the call against this check and safely remove the check to `Base.Ready()` as you correctly guessed it could change between those two calls so we don't gain anything.
So to answer your question concretely  - no, we don't need a lock and we also don't need the `Ready` check as we can rely on `Base.GetStatus` to give us the accurate information.

comments_data.body:
Any specific reason we allow consumers to change this?

I don't think these should be props. I think FolderPicker should be a very specific and opinionated component with a consistent as possible experience everywhere.

yes, my idea was applying this change only to `RuleFolderPicker`, and once we see that it works as we expect, remove the prop and extend the functionality to the rest of consumers. Do you think it's better to apply the changes directly to the FolderPicker?

removing props is a breaking change, so if it's our intention for these to be temporary then I think they should be named as such to discourage others from using/relying on them.

I don't think this is particuarly risky - do you?. I'll discuss today with the rest of the team, but I think we should be confident enough to just use this everywhere.

Besides, we've had a bunch of regressions with FolderPicker and search, so I would want to test thoroughly either way :)

> removing props is a breaking change, so if it's our intention for these to be temporary then I think they should be named as such to discourage others from using/relying on them.

💯 you're right!

> I don't think this is particuarly risky - do you?.

I don't, honestly, I was not sure about how to proceed, but I agree with you, we should apply the changes for al consumers.

> I'll discuss today with the rest of the team

thank you @joshhunt !
I'm thinking that maybe it's a good idea, letting consumers decide the value for the limit? So having a default limit but applying `sliceResults` prop in case of having it? wdyt @joshhunt

We discussed this today - we agree that FolderPicker should have a consistent experience everywhere, and should not expose these props or controls to users. I cannot think of a reason why consumers would want to pick a different size for the 'slicing' - if the default for FolderPicker is not suitable for a particular use case, it should be not suitable for everyone.
We should not be setting the width explicitly because this breaks it in other places where this component is used, do we 100% want to change the width for alerting?
Don't need this extra constant if it is set to the default value anyway, wdyt?
it make sense, I will update the PR then 👍
true, let me check it 👀
yes!! I forgot to remove it, thank you! @JoaoSilvaGrafana
Removed ✅ @JoaoSilvaGrafana
I've just updated the PR making always the slice in FolderPicker ✅ @joshhunt 👀
not related to this PR, but removed because we are not using it .

I'm thinking it might be useful to link the original issue or [PR description ](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/61221#issue-1527230780) here so that anyone that wonders about this slicing can have some context given this is a shared component.
nit: perhaps we should keep this variable named `options` and call the slice `optionsSlice` or `reducedOptionsSet` or something similar – this reads a bit more logical to me.
Does the interface want this to be an async function? I'm not sure if we want to return a promise unless we have to.
I'm not sure if we need to call attention to this, this is only relevant to a user that wants to select something by scrolling all the way to the end of the list without additional filters, right?
Why was `t('folder-picker.loading', 'Loading folders...')` removed? I see `t` is used in a few other places. I don't know if we should apply it for user visible texts everywhere or not.

yes, we need because loadOptions requires a Promise
`loadOptions?: (inputValue: string, callback: (options: OptionsOrGroups<Option, Group>) => void) => Promise<OptionsOrGroups<Option, Group>> | void;`
yes, I think as user can scroll down the 1000 items (it's really fast to do that), we should warn someway that we are limiting the results.
I removed this in this commit because I added it wrongly. I think we agreed with @gillesdemey not to add new ones until we decide applying the translation everywhere.

We finally decided to not slice in the FE, so this constant has been removed. We will limit the results adding the limit in the api. Your are right though, I will update the PR description as some decisions have been done in the middle.
Las commit removes this slicing in the FE.
Removing the warning, as we should add the same in the group list and it looks very redundant.

commits_data.message: introduce flag and populate via feature toggle check
update instance database to support exclusion of state in list operation
do not save normal state and delete transitions to normal
update get methods to filter out normal state
get rid of feature fake in favor common approach

Merge branch 'up/main' into yuri-tceretian/statemanager-reduce-saves

# Conflicts:

#	pkg/services/ngalert/ngalert.go

Merge branch 'up/main' into yuri-tceretian/statemanager-reduce-saves

# Conflicts:
#	pkg/services/ngalert/state/cache.go

comments_data.body: Can we artificially assume this state instead of putting this behind a feature flag then? As in, could we assume (and insert at runtime) a new state that would assume normal when a previous state its state is missing.

we can artificially assume a state for a rule, but we cannot assume a state for each rule's instances when Grafana starts. The normal state will be available only after the first evaluation once Grafana starts, which can be in 1s or 1h or more.

I mean this from a presentation point of view. From state management pov we already do this (i.e. artificially assume a new instance to be in normal state. The difference is in presentation: currently, we show instances with normal state in UI, with this feature flag enabled, we are not able to show until the first evaluation after the restart. Therefore, I decided to not show it at all because it could be confusing (especially in environments when Grafana can be restarted at any time, like K8s)

Can we refactor the constructor args to a struct like `state.ManagerOptions`, kind of like we did for the scheduler? https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/2505f112f5e140e7ba45be82e27ecfc977a5aeea/pkg/services/ngalert/schedule/schedule.go#L104

The boolean argument that significantly changes the behavior is a bit confusing IMO.

I wonder if we should dependency inject all of `FeatureToggles` rather than passing this bool around everywhere. I realize it's more overhead, but the bool hurts readability at call sites IMO.

And, if we decide we like this change and want to make it always-on (removing the toggle), it's going to be a pain to dig back through all this code and remove the args.
`doNotKeepNormalState` == `skipNormalState`? This is another reason why i'd prefer just using the toggle directly, it's less ambiguous and less intrusive to the existing code.
Can we kill this line and just `result := make([]*State, 0, len(rs.states))` on 239?

Per my comment on https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/61201#discussion_r1066034793 I was hoping we could make an argument for removing the feature flag w/o necessarily incurring in a breaking change. 

I think the feature flag makes this more complicated and doesn't really buy us anything (it is a breaking change but a very subtle one) - could we maybe assume that until determined by the next evaluation when a rule starts it's normal in order to keep semantics equal? The way I understand this if an instance would have no state to recover from it's because it was either:

A) never present 
B) not recorded because it was normal

Sure, that would solve my comment here too, I'm just not a fan of the boolean flags permeating the code that deeply change its behavior. If we do this a couple times, we end up with a large matrix of boolean toggles and things become hard to follow. Just having one path is a solution here - but if we must have two, I'd rather it be flagged each place it's used.

My intention is to keep the feature flag until Grafana 10 when we can reason about breaking changes. Although there is only one breaking change, in the presentation, I think it is still a breaking one and should be handled accordingly - we should make it default in the next major version. 

re features toggle, I am really on the fence. I did that initially but then decided to use the flag because backtesting creates a state manager and therefore it needs a feature manager just to read that toggle, and create a fake one was kinda messy, as well as propagating feature manager. Anyway, I see your point, and will update to use toggles.
Oh, I actually like this approach. Will do it
renamed to DoNotSaveNormalState, which I think more close to what it does

I strongly agree with Alex's remark about using a boolean parameter to change the behavior of a function. That's a low-hanging fruit and we should change it. Have two functions or use the options pattern.

If we abstract from the fact that this is a feature flag, the argument here makes perfect sense: a caller requests all abnormal states. I can agree that it could look obscure and unobvious in a public API like the constructor method of the state manager. However, I do not see any problems with methods, especially when it is the only boolean argument.
Providing an entire feature manager is what is very ambiguous and obscure because it makes it unclear what flags and how they are used. It is like providing an entire Grafana config just to read one field two layers down.

> Providing an entire feature manager is what is very ambiguous

I'd agree with this for a lot of objects, but generally a feature flag structure intentionally reverses this rule:
1. It's clear at each point the flag is checked that it's a flagged code, not a permanent config toggle.
2. It makes the flag checks less intrusive, and easier to remove in the future.

Especially passing the boolean as part of the function signature, this will have to go through back and be refactored out later when we decide to drop the toggle and make this default behavior.

Could we add some context to the name here?

After reading the signature, I'd expect `IsNormalState` to return true if `State` == `eval.Normal` and not care about `StateReason`. I realize there is a comment, but I think the name should reflect that in some way, especially since the name is exported.
Makes sense. Updated!

I still think that the bool argument is better than the feature manager in this particular case because the cache implementation has different methods like `getOrCreate`, `removeByRuleUID`, `get` that return state(s). Conceptually, having a feature flag changing the behavior of just a subset of methods would make it less clear what is going on and why different methods of the cache return different data. 
the flag there is purely for optimization purposes - to avoid filtering the slice in the manager.

title: Kindsys: Unify plugins, pfs with kind framework

commits_data.message: Reached codegen parity with old system
All tests passing, nearly good now
Allow forcing ExpandReferences on go type generation
Move DataQuery def into kindsys, add generator to copy it to common
Fix copy generator to replace package name correctly

comments_data.body:
This PR changes the names of the schema interfaces - formerly known as "slots" - to these new names:

* `Panel` -> `PanelCfg`
* `Query` -> `DataQuery`
* `DSOptions` -> `DataSourceCfg`

Talking about "the panel slot" was really ambiguous with "panel" ([the base type](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/9cdcbab2fc3b5508077cb5e9715bcf7d99c7c4d8/kinds/dashboard/dashboard_kind.cue#L333) defined in the dashboard schema) and with panel plugins themselves. While more verbose, i think "the panelcfg schema interface" is a significant improvement.

We haven't been using the other two schema interfaces yet. However, we've begun testing the waters and mobbing on some `DataQuery` and `DataSourceConfig` implementations, and it looks like these should be in good enough shape for teams to make meaningful progress with them on schema day.

I'm going to put up some separate PRs (targeted against this one) to illustrate.

The fact that we're not injecting a `joinSchema` here basically means that we're not actually enforcing the schema interface-defined rules on the composable kinds declared by plugins. That means that `ParsePluginFS` validation won't fail if, for example, it encounters a `PanelCfg` lineage that lacks a `PanelOptions` field.

I've commented it out for now because there's a bug in how cuetsy deals with the additional unifications when it comes to generating enums. It's mostly just a sign of cuetsy needing a deeper refactor, but i believe the problem will likely also go away when grafana/thema#82 goes in. So, given that we're still not realistically rolling this out outside of Grafana core for at least a few more months and it's easy enough to notice and fix any plugin not following the pattern in core, this seems like an OK hack for now.

We're now ensuring/injecting a `cue.mod` directory into all plugins, including core ones. That means we're effectively treating core plugins as being logically outside the grafana CUE module.

i haven't seen any problems with this...yet? and it's modeling the world we want, so 🎉

In writing this PR, i glimpsed another significant simplification.

Most of the jennies written so far are based on `DeclForGen`, which are basically a validated `cue.Value` + a validated `thema.Lineage`. I originally called them that because i was thinking about them in contrast to [the `type Kind struct`](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/a277d504a2b258d01be3a1aa401a19a33b8c817d/pkg/kinds/dashboard/dashboard_kind_gen.go#L24-L33) that we generate in `pkg/kinds/*/` and which implements [one of the main kindsys interfaces](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/a277d504a2b258d01be3a1aa401a19a33b8c817d/pkg/kindsys/kind.go). What defines those structs is that they contain [references to the generated Go type](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/a277d504a2b258d01be3a1aa401a19a33b8c817d/pkg/kinds/dashboard/dashboard_kind_gen.go#L26).

My error was in thinking that because the jennies needed something generic, that meant they needed something _other_ than an implementation of one of those main interfaces. But, as this file here demonstrates, that's actually exactly what they need. That means we can get rid of this "*ForGen" nonsense, and create parallel funcs for `BindCustom` and `BindCore` that correspond to structs like `genericComposable` here, and that'll be what generic parts of the system (including codegen, but also e.g. in the apiserver) actually depend on.

It does make sense to have this here, in terms of `pkg/plugins` being the space where most plugin things get defined. But it's really kinda properly a part of kindsys, at minimum because we can't really evaluate changes to `Composable` over there without looking at this, as well.


I'd be interested in opinions from @grafana/plugins-platform  on moving it to `pkg/kindsys`

I added this `pascalName` field to `plugindef` because without it, i was going in circles on how to align composable kinds with [the general naming system for kinds](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/447e56b557310517f3e3fd1e0e1a5cac3d220bc5/pkg/kindsys/kindcats.cue#L29-L54). This value (along with id) is [injected](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/61192/files#diff-2910f3982292a1758b4b3aca45ea9e7f032773018451d91e2f8f63323146ebaaR210-R217) into [the `grafanaplugin` cue instance](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/61192/files#diff-f1d8e8d9498df64f5c6be3b0b25813d68a4891c14a78e10cac068d0a4b9823ebR12), and then used to construct a name for the composable kind. Thus, we end up with an identifier - used really for codegen, since composable kinds aren't ever a root resource - that looks like, say, 

To be clear, i'm not actually convinced we _have_ to make composable kinds follow the same naming patterns/that they make sense as for core and custom kinds. But this is the path of lesser resistance for now, and given that naming is hard, i think this is fine _for now_ and we can look at naming again in a follow-up.

There is some weird bug, i think in thema, which is causing the computed value (what's in `sani`) to not make it out when deserializing to a Go struct. So for now, there's [duplicate logic](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/61192/files#diff-61f85a08bd5f398219965af5c1e4090ca2d24da0a5c2da35a70140693d9e31ddR43) to do this in Go (actually a bit more expressive, we can deal with it when the bug is fixed).
Jooc, what's the goal, or what are the actual implications of turning `Maturity` from a definition into a value? 🤔
Do we have a filed issue with the details? 🤔
**Question**: Do we have a plan how to handle changes over time for these kind of types?
Do we have any issue somewhere to keep track of things like this that we need to fix before we can expose this to external plugin developers?
yes, these have to be strictly controlled - only forwards _and_ backwards compatible changes are permissible.
A checker to ensure that invariant is prerequisite to being able to mark any of our individual kinds as stable.

It has no real effect here. But it's primarily about consistency with the need to not use definitions elsewhere (e.g. i have to change ~all of Thema's base cue types), because of how they recursively close anything within them. That creates a bunch of problems when the things inside a definition are arbitrary schema - such as are contained within the `Core`, `Custom`, and `Composable` kind defs in kindsys, here. So, getting away from that is the _desired_ effect of not using definitions.

Unfortunately, IMO CUE kinda overloads definitions with a bunch of things - they're not included in default output from e.g. `cue eval`, and many of its encoders/generators treat being a definition as indicative that a thing should be generated. i don't know what all else we might run into with it, but the recursive closing issue is so problematic for schema definitions that are useful outside of CUE that we're just going to have to deal with whatever come sup.
@IfSentient you may find this of interest
I think we should move it to `pkg/kindsys` since it is a definition of how you can extend the kindsys of Grafana.
This is already defined in the dashboard types so we need to remove one of them.
ahh, our first problem with the shared namespacing!
Actually it seems to be the same type just defined in two places, had the same issue for another panel.
Nit. Maybe `PanelOptions` is more suitable given https://grafana.com/docs/grafana/next/panels-visualizations/configure-panel-options/ ? Or instead of `Cfg` use `Config` of `Configuration`
Sorry I just realize that `PanelOptions` is a child property of `PanelCfg`
Seems like the Levitate check fails due to DataSourceRef being exported twice.
And the frontend lint step

No strong opinions. But felt earlier when moving everything plugin related under plugins package we wanted the kind package to be as generic as possible without any details of how plugins are being found/parsed. Is it possible to move some stuff and keep some perhaps?
Does this `TODO` relate to the fact that `datasource` can no longer be `null`, just `undefined` | `DataSourceRef`?

no, we're not actually enforcing the no-nulls rule yet, though...needs to happen soon.

It's about the mixed datasource type busting up clear abstraction layers. This field (target-level) is _only_ expected to be populated when when the mixed datasource is in use at the panel level. Thus, we're effectively leaking information from the container/dashboard level down into the plugin.
Not important for this pr, but long term we should try to avoid the whole `import * as x from 'package'` pattern since it makes the tree shaking a bit trickier.
This is more of a personal preference but not a big fan of the `composable_` notation. I would prefer to use dataquery.cue in this case.
Something we can do after this PR is merged but I think we can refactor so this is moved to the kindsys pakage and we return something similar to PluginDecl from the kindsys instead.

I was wondering since it's only types do we even need tree shaking? I realise that in this case we also have default values there but if those were separated would that eliminate the need for tree shaking?

comments_data.body:
```suggestion | `plugins:*`
`plugins:id:*` | Restrict an action to a set of application plugins. For example, `plugins:id:grafana-oncall-app` matches Grafana OnCall plugin, and `plugins:*` matches all application plugins. | ```

```suggestion
| `plugins:install`                    | n/a                                                                                     | Install and uninstall plugins.                                                                                                                                                       |
```

`plugins:id:*` | Edit settings for one or more plugins. | ```

comments_data.body: What is the effect of leaving this title empty? Specially in terms of accessibility.

That's a very good question. The title serves as the `aria-label` for the whole alert, and as such I think ideally we don't want to leave the title out - or provide the aria-label somehow else. 

In this case for example we wanted to leave the title out to make the alert more compact and take up less height, so it doesn't push the original content down that much.

I am not sure how to do this easily to be honest, as there can be cases where we don't want the title on the UI, however we would still like to have an `aria-label` for the sake of accessibility. Without changing the props of the Alert component maybe we could add it on the call-site to the element that wraps the Alert component?
There are ways you can set an aria label for an element from other element. See `aria-labelledby`. Generally speaking we should not leave this without an aria label.

Yepp, above I meant `aria-labelledby`, that's what we are using in Alert today. The problem is that if there is no title, then the referenced element is empty. I am not really sure how to support this design from an accessibility perspective, the only way I can imagine would be to introduce a new prop on the Alert component, e.g. something like `hideTitle`, but I think that would be a bit too much.

**Update:** just had a quick chat with @academo, and as an end result I will probably try introducing a new prop called `ariaLabel`, which could use the title as a fallback value in case it's not defined.
**Update 2.0:** I have decided to move most of the `<Alert>` related changes to a separate PR so they are easier to be looked at: https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/61242

comments_data.body: Any particular reason to inline this in 2 places?

Previously it's been a shared function, now since the order of injection has changed (instead of Cfg we take CommandLineArgs, and use Cfg from the instantiated Runner) - I decided to have this code duplicated. But yeah, there is a way to unify this again.
this might be a good time to add some comments about the difference between these sets, and suggestions for what new things go where (if you have an idea. I don't).

Ideally, everything should go into `wireBasicSet`. CLISet I hope would not be needed soon (need to look into enterprise) and it could be instantiated from the same BasicSet graph as would the Server.
Now, wireTestSet is a question. I'd prefer to see it gone and let unit tests inject dependencies (mock) manually, as most of them do already. Integration tests on the other hand should rather use real implementations when possible. We should be able to move prefs and sqlstore into the basic set. NGAlert and Notifications are terra incognita to me, but I hope there would be a solution to mock them in a similar manner without a separate wire graph.
TLDR: I hope there would be one wireSet once this is all finished. What we have now is there "for legacy reasons".

I'm still not sure the extent to which we interact with these sets on a day-to-day basis, but I second documenting these guidelines somehow. Your comment seems like a pretty complete overview already. The documentation could be something along the lines of the [Queries with Result Fields](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/15804234d6ea8d803def4edf802d142e418979f1/contribute/backend/communication.md#queries-with-result-fields) section, which describes how to refactor away Result fields. I suppose the guidelines you describe could be added to the [Services](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/15804234d6ea8d803def4edf802d142e418979f1/contribute/backend/services.md) section, which already includes an introduction to wire.

comments_data.body: this change won't be saved unless you run `onChange`, no?

you can do: 
```suggestion
    expect(screen.getByText('metric.test_label')).toBeInTheDocument();
```
which is a bit more idiomatic.

you don't need `await` in this line
```suggestion
    openMenu(service);
```

and an alternative here would be:

```suggestion
    expect(screen.queryByText('metric.test_label')).not.toBeInTheDocument();
```
I would create a `defaultProps` object that you can reuse in all the tests
I think you can use `TimeOption` from `@grafana/data` here as the type.

this is a bit brittle, if you remove `timeState` here, nothing will tell you that you are breaking this. I see that `getLabels` is using `this.timeSrv.timeRange()`. Why don't you store the `TimeRange` in the state instead and pass it as an argument? That way you are sure that you are calling `getLabels` with the right range.
Updating the service value triggers `onChange` as it causes the `onMetricTypeChange` function to be called 😊

It is slightly brittle but I think it's fairly safe as we also use `groupBys`, and `crossSeriesReducer`. I can add a comment here explicitly detailing why these 3 are there but it should be implied that if they're included in the dependency array it's to ensure `getLabels` is re-ran when one of them changes. 

There isn't a need to pass `TimeRange` as an arg as the value used within the function would be the correct one. I feel if we were to pass it as an arg it's more likely we could accidentally set the wrong range here.

mmh, that would be relying on an indirect reference. `onMetricTypeChange` is getting the `query` object from `VisualMetricQueryEditor`, not from this component so it's a miracle if that works :sweat_smile:

I would move the definition of `onMetricTypeChange` to this component (since it's only used here) and explicitly build a full `query` object here that is used for the main `onChange` so it's explicit.

not passing `groupBys` and `crossSeriesReducer` as arguments already sounds like a bug and I don't know if that's on purpose :sweat_smile: 

> There isn't a need to pass TimeRange as an arg as the value used within the function would be the correct one

yes, but it feels more natural to calculate it here since this component is the one in charge of re-calling the function in case the TimeRange here. You are calculating the `time` here just to detect changes and recalculate the `range`. Isn't it simpler to just calculate the range and store that?
That's a good point and moving the definition of `onMetricTypeChange` makes sense!

Also a good point. I'm now considering doing a bigger refactor of the `VisualMetricQueryEditor` because I'm not entirely sure why this component is separate to the `Metrics` component when there isn't much in that component specifically, wdyt?
yep, makes sense!
:oof: tricky test :sweat_smile:
I find that usually `act` is not needed, for example if you wait for the text 'Srv' to be there it should work the same way

why not
```suggestion
  const [timeRange, setTimeRange] = useState<TimeRange>({ ...datasource.timeSrv.timeRange() });
```
?
I don't think you need this assign, in  `if` condition below, `onMetricTypeChange` is doing the same, and in the `else` the query is not being updated anyway :shrug:
🤣  I finally got it working and I'm very happy about this
Without the `act` I have the error related to causing the state to be updated outside of `act` so I think it's safer to keep them in?
Good shout!
This is partially true, I can change this to just set the `filters` value to `[]` as the assign in `onMetricTypeChange` conserves the value.

comments_data.body: why do we change this behaviour?

I think some fields allow UTF-8 characters (like emojis) in alert rule names – some values do support all characters.

Perhaps something like `![\\\n]+` could work as an additional token?
Do you think we could traversing the list of namespaces only once? filtering namespace and dataSourceName at the same time?
That's super cool!!! 🚀 It would be very useful to add comments to this part of the code like, how do you preserve the order, etc...

I don't think we should support these short-hand aliases and might add an additional maintenance burden. 

A few reasons I've mention in our review call;

* It assumes readers of the query know the keyword the short-hand refers to
* It adds additional code maintenance for them in the search code
* Adds additional complexity when we want to add additional features
	(ie. if we wanted to implement some sort of "type-ahead", we'd also have to make it work for these and the single character letters could add additional complexity to the code)
Perhaps we should default this to a `noop` instead of checking if it's defined?
I think we can shorten this to `Boolean(fs?.length)`? Can it be something other than `string` or `Array`?
Dito shorter check without ternary as above
What about making it a required prop? If the component always shows a "Clear filters" button then it should know what to do when clicked in all cases.
why is it called `ngFilters`? `ng` takes me back to angular 😞
What do you think of abstracting this condition into a `const`? it's hard to tell what it checks for at a glance.
Is this @todo left there on purpose?
Would it also work with single quotes?
Nice!
what about using the `isEmpty` from lodash?

title: Reduce CI time for backports by removing levitate workflow

commits_data.message:
Reduce CI time for backports by removing levitate workflow

The levitate workflow detects breaking changes and this only makes
sense on the main branch.

By removing this workflow we will save around five minutes of
contributor and CI CPU time on each backport.

Signed-off-by: Jack Baldry <jack.baldry@grafana.com>

commits_data.message: add missing checks, make linter happy
Merge branch 'main' of https://github.com/grafana/grafana into mark_am_configurations_as_applied
fix deadlock, mark as valid on save and on load
Merge branch 'main' of https://github.com/grafana/grafana into mark_am_configurations_as_applied
Merge branch 'main' of https://github.com/grafana/grafana into mark_am_configurations_as_applied

comments_data.body: Idea: What if we marked _all_ rows with the same hash? If it's the same hash, it's the same config! Not sure what others think here.

I thought about that, but I decided to update just the latest row for two main reasons:
1. Marking all identical configs as applied at the same time would mean using the same timestamp. We could end up with the same config stored in different points in time but "applied" in the exact same second.
2. We would also have to check for `0` or `NULL` in the the `applied_at` column before the update. Otherwise, we would end up overwriting this field for older configs just because the hash is the same.

I think it would be misleading to fill this column for older rows with the timestamp that's actually for the latest row. The config is the same, but the data is not accurate and it could be misleading both for users (this is supposed to be shown in the UI) and for us in case we have to troubleshoot something related to applied configs.

This would be less of a problem if we were using a boolean, but it would also not be 100% accurate (e.g. suppose we have a config that was valid one year ago but is not anymore).
error handling should come before the `if` statement above.
Nice catch, thanks!
Do we need this column in both tables? We only ever read it from the history one.
Is `applied_at != 0` correct? Since it's nullable, won't this return rows with a null `applied_at`?
This wouldn't be covered by the current tests, too - we should add a test for the negative case here - that includes a non-applied configuration, and asserts that it's not returned.

IMO it's similarly not accurate to mark the history entry with most recent ID and that configuration hash. What if the same configuration appears multiple times in history? We don't know that the user actually picked the most recent one right?

I added this field in the `alert_configuration` table in my last commit. We need this field to know whether a config is already marked as applied or not. That way when Grafana starts and we load an already marked configuration, we know we don't need to mark it as applied again.

> Is applied_at != 0 correct? Since it's nullable, won't this return rows with a null applied_at?

Since the type in the struct is `int64` (not a pointer), the value always defaults to `0`.
Do you know in which case it could be saved as null if we're not using a pointer? Or do you think there's a better option? E.g, making the field not nullable and deal with zero-values.

> This wouldn't be covered by the current tests, too - we should add a test for the negative case here - that includes a non-applied configuration, and asserts that it's not returned.

Totally agree. I was planning on doing this in my next PR. This PR focuses on the write path, the next one will focus on the logic for retrieving records and API-specific things. This method is currently only used in tests.

Unless I'm missing something, yes, the user will always be using the latest config in the history table as I explained in my [comment](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/61330#issuecomment-1387226993).
If a user picks an older config then that config gets re-saved, generating a new record in the history table. So, even if the same config appears multiple times, and even if the applied config is a previous config, the last one is the one in use.

I think the default of 0 is dangerous:
1. It's a nullable int, can't we set `DEFAULT NULL` and make the default whatever we like?
2. This is a unix timestamp, `0` can be interpreted as `1970-01-01T00:00:00Z`.

If we disagree with the above points and would rather still keep 0 as the default "empty" representation, let's make the column `nullable: false` instead. Let's settle on one default representation here, and not have two different ones.

You're right! 0 could be interpreted as Jan 1st 1970, that's why I treat this value as an `int64` everywhere (both struct and DB). We use `int64` for other timestamps, e.g. `created_at`.

> It's a nullable int, can't we set DEFAULT NULL and make the default whatever we like?

Could you explain this a bit more in depth?

I'm totally open to changing this default value, I agree it could be dangerous. However, I currently can't see how having a pointer to a value is any less dangerous, and I think I'm not getting which other values could be used instead.

I agree with making the column not nullable if we decide to stick with ints.

Missing a field:
```suggestion
			CreatedAt:                 time.Now().Unix(),
			AppliedAt:                 cmd.AppliedAt,
```

That check can be moved to the database with something like `update where id=? and applied_at is null` ( or 0) which should allow us to keep this column off of `alert_configuration` if we want to.

To make sure we don't increase the number of database calls we just make sure that `MarkConfigurationAsApplied` is gated by the [config hash change check](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/0be920e61c778f410011f2fbb210279f5f8758d1/pkg/services/ngalert/notifier/alertmanager.go#L270) in `applyConfig`. Either by putting it directly in that method or returning a boolean from it, or simply rechecking the hash yourself.

Would play nice into the change @alexweav mentions above to mark all hashes in the history at the same time (though I'm not sure where I stand on that one, both options seem ok to me).

Agree with @alexweav here, either (nullable+null) or (not null + 0). 

In addition, why shouldn't we use `time.Time` instead of `int64`? Seems even clearer to me.

After talking with @JacobsonMT and @alexweav, consensus is using an `int64` and using not null + 0 (that's how we're currently handling timestamps [in other places](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/c6f4eb4282192bac212f5987960bc29d76261ee3/pkg/services/ngalert/models/alertmanager.go#L12)).
I don't think `ConfigID` is used anywhere anymore.
Please move this to the end of `AddTablesMigrations`

Great idea! I'm gonna add just the `xorm:"extends"` tag for now, not sure how we'll handle translating this into JSON yet (API layer struct?), and we're not gonna use it here, so it's better to leave that for the next PR.
We should do each parameter on a new line, or all on one line - not a mixture of both
Missing CreatedAt?
Did we re-order the cleanup and the new config insert? I think we still want to kick off the cleanup at the very end
Is this even possible given that the query has `Limit(1)`? Should we check it at all?

```suggestion
// GetAppliedConfigurations returns all configurations that have been marked as applied, ordered newest -> oldest by id.
```
Nit: Newest->oldest by applied date, or by ID, may not be exactly the same thing

```suggestion
	t.Run("when calling the cleanup with fewer records than the limit all records should stay", func(t *testing.T) {
```
If we're already on the topic of grammar, there's this too :laughing:

```suggestion
		require.NoError(tt, err)
		require.Len(tt, query.Result, 0)
```
Let's assert that marking the config as applied actually did something.

```suggestion
    // LastApplied is the most recent time at which the configuration was applied to an Alertmanager, or 0 otherwise. Only set this field if the configuration has been applied by the caller.
	LastApplied        int64 `xorm:"last_applied"`
```

title: Explore: Create DataSourceWithSupplementaryQueriesSupport interface to support log volume and samples

commits_data.message: Create DataSourceWithLogsSampleSupport check and move to 1 place
Add and change utility functions for loading, storing ancd checking supp queries
Add logic to redux for processing of new type of supp query
Implement queryLogsSample used to run samples queries
Fix tests to include also Log samples
Refactor handling of supplementary queries in query.ts
Remove changes for any => unknowns as in utils.ts
Fix incorrect imports after function was moved to different file
Merge branch 'ivana/log-sample-logic' of https://github.com/grafana/grafana into ivana/log-sample-logic
Refactor, improve tests,  change internal API
Add deprecation for DataSourceWithLogsVolumeSupport, but still support it
Update comment with correct new issue

comments_data.body: Do we really need to use observables here? I can't find the use case and the produced code is very obscure.
Why can't we use an actual `TimeRange` instance here? Because this is not a test. Same for `AbsoluteTimeRange`.
Is it possible to make it more generic so we don't have `if` for each type, but rather iterate over all of them?
I added this fix thinking it is a test file. I removed this changes in https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/61298/commits/ff905e3773a715b1548971d203d163389cd1d873

Good idea! I have refactored it in https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/61298/commits/e9a6a1d3c66b4d5856ea833345ace1afea4e8706. (I removed redundant Object.values when looping over supplementaryQueriesList in https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/61298/commits/41abe6411b9b44a77526ab713d04be7d492785b7. I forgot to fix it in first commit.) And then I fixed additional bug in logic in https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/61298/commits/b31a65fabed8c3412ab82b647a1a7584425651f8.

Let me know what do you think

If we query data source, the result is already an observable. And we need a way how to initially set loading state to show loading indicator, then if query/observable produces error, then correctly set up error state for query.  If you have any specific thought/idea in mind, let me know.

Hmm... I wonder if it'd make sense to have just one `DataSourceWithSupplementaryQueriesSupport` interface and with a method:

```typescript
getDataProvider(type: SupplementaryQueryType, requestDataQueryRequest<TQuery>): Observable<DataQueryResponse> | undefined;
```

![](https://media.giphy.com/media/Oc4KnIJ3E7ziqN3l6T/giphy.gif)
That's a lot of copy-pasta 🍝  Not sure if we need it since you made the logic more generic 🤔  Or maybe we could have one mock that implements both providers and merge all tests cases?
Also if we had unified interface mentioned earlier (DataSourceWithSupplementaryQueriesSupport) we could make the test simpler.
same as before for all the added tests here, `dispatch` is not async, there's no need to `await` it or mark the test as async

Good idea! I implemented it in https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/61298/commits/549a22f1f13b9ed668f7ab3cbbd9e0ba133fbaaf. I created `DataSourceWithSupplementaryQueriesSupport` and deprecated `DataSourceWithLogsVolumeSupport`. Currently, logic at couple places isn't looking the best because we need to support both `DataSourceWithLogsVolumeSupport` and `DataSourceWithSupplementaryQueriesSupport`, but as soon as we remove `DataSourceWithLogsVolumeSupport`, it is going to be much cleaner. 

I haven't changed tests, cause I wanted to agree on solution before updating those. 

Let me know what do you think @ifrost @Elfo404

@ivanahuckova removing this file from grafana-data breaks our plugins API. If you are planning on removing this and replacing them for others, please follow the procedure of deprecating them in this PR and only removing them in the next major version.

Hello @academo! Is this needed as `DataSourceWithLogsVolumeSupport` API had `@internal` tag and we suspected that it might change?  We replaced this with more generic `DataSourceWithSupplementaryQueriesSupport` and implemented change for all internal plugins that were using `DataSourceWithLogsVolumeSupport`.

```suggestion
 * This will enable users to see additional data when running original queries.
```
Hi @ivanahuckova I checked the information we have on API usage and I could not find any external plugins using it. so go ahead with merging this PR

The [TencentCloud](https://github.com/TencentCloud/tencentcloud-monitor-grafana-app/blob/1b1b240989b27fe111498539cbc109ef8ac97ff2/src/datasource/log-service/LogServiceDataSource.ts#L198) is not implementing an API, so there is no issue. 

However [newrelic](https://github.com/grafana/newrelic-datasource/blob/main/src/datasource/Datasource.ts#L99) is implementing and using it (fyi @yesoreyeram). 

Considering this API was marked as `@internal`, would you recommend to:
- keep this PR in this form and let NewRelic data source maintainers know about this
- keep this PR in this form, but add `breaking change` label and let NewRelic data source maintainers know about this
- Change PR to deprecate old API and introduce new one. And then in v10, break the old API
- Something else
The course of actions should be deprecate the API and only remove it in the next major version
👍 I brought `DataSourceWithLogsVolumeSupport` back and deprecated it: https://github.com/grafana/grafana/commit/f5be7ad433a062d94fad18d9d08da3435382cac9.

Did you mean?

```suggestion
            // TODO: Remove after v10 (#61296)
```
I wanted to link this PR as reference to what should be removed.
But I can create issue for us - log squad and link that
Changed in https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/61298/commits/578d9b0f20abd68d9e698bd8a709f9d8716ca5b6 and new issue is here https://github.com/grafana/grafana/issues/61845

comments_data.body: What do you think about naming this just `lineLimit` or `maxLines`?
Just a nit here, but I think we prefer to list the optional properties in an object last.
Stupid edge case, but if a user enters `0` - which is falsely - as the linelimit for a query, the UI then show `dsMaxLines`. Do you have a good idea how we could circumvent it?

@svennergr i have fixed the ui rendering issue here, but in terms of functionality what would you like to happen here when the user selects a line limit of `0`?

there are two options we could take
1 - render 0 log lines, thats what the user wanted 🧐

my preferred is `2`, but i would like a second opinion on this.

comments_data.body: Why do we adjust the index to `locations[0]-1`? On previous line we set `current.locationID = locations[0]` but then seem to add lines from parent location?

they are indexed starting with 1 for the id. 

profile.Location[0].ID = 1

Mainly trying to understand how this works and the format. Looking at pprof format there does not seem to be anything that would prescribe what the IDs should be, it basically says it can be random. Here I assume this is a result of how Phlare creates the pprof data and that by conventions I assume it sets ID to be 1 based so as you mentioned `profile.Location[0].ID = 1` is that right?
Correct.
