title: Docs: Update visualization and barchart panels

comments_data.body:
```suggestion
When the graph is vertically oriented, this setting rotates the labels under the bars. This setting is useful when bar chart labels are long and overlap.
```

```suggestion
### Rotate x-axis tick labels
```

```suggestion
### X-axis tick label maximum length
```

```suggestion
Sets the maximum length of bar chart labels. Labels longer than the maximum length are truncated, and appended with `...`.
```

```suggestion
Controls bar chart stacking.
```

```suggestion
Controls the radius of the bars. 
- 0 = Minimum radius
- 0.5 = Maximum radius
```

```suggestion
Controls if the entire surrounding area of the bar is highlighted when you hover over the bar.
```
I don't understand what this means. could you explain more or perhaps provide an example?

```suggestion
- **Off**: Bars will not be stacked.
```

```suggestion
- **Normal**: Bars will be stacked on each other.
```

```suggestion
- **Percent**: Bars will be stacked on each other, and the height of each bar is the percentage of the total height of the stack.
```
If "x-tick" is the label in the UI, we should file a UX bug to get it changed to "x-axis".  X Tick may be the option name in the code, but it should not be the label presented to users.

I looked into providing an example and possibly discovered a bug. My understanding of this was that you could color the bars representing some values by the color of a different field in the dataset. The more I think about it the more confusing I find it aswell since the legend seems to show wrong values when this setting is set.

I have removed the doc for this option and will look into it's functionality better. Will probably come back with a new docs PR when I figure if there are bugs or my understanding is wrong of it.
Yes, the UI shows `X tick`. I will open a UI bug for this. I assume the process is the one found in creating a new issue through github.

we have two different sets of labels in bar chart. x axis tick labels, which is what this is referring to. and bar values "labels", which is the value text rendered above each bar.

we should make sure not to confuse these two by calling either bar chart labels. or just make sure there is consistency.

you can choose another field to use for coloring the bars. that field can be something like status strings: "pass", "fail". then you set up value mappings (or thresholds) on that field to control the colors.

https://play.grafana.org/d/barchart-thresholds-mappings/barchart-thresholds-and-mappings?orgId=1

yes, the legend might need some more work.
see original PR for more use cases "build status" bars. https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/43257

Okay, I understand. Then I guess we should actually add it in the docs... maybe something like `Color bars based on another field's values.` And possibly add this PASS/FAIL with value mappings example in there somehow?

title: ElasticSearch: Improve ES error handling message

commits_data.message:
Look for 'caused_by.reason' in ES error response

When the ES response does not contain `reason` or `root_cause[0].reason`
is empty, there is no information for the user to know what is going
wrong.

An example of the error message after this change:
```
Failed to evaluate queries and expressions: failed to execute query A: Trying to create too many buckets. Must be less than or equal to: [65536] but this number of buckets was exceeded. This limit can be set by changing the [search.max_buckets] cluster level setting.
```

Related to https://github.com/grafana/grafana/issues/61246

comments_data.body:
could you please only do the `case causedByReason` switch, and not change the `default` case?

i understand the motivation (provide more debugging info in an unforeseen situation), but we are very careful with what we return intoto the browser, in case it contains something sensitive. and considering the `case causedByReason` fixes the current problem, i recommend only changing that, it will make the PR merged easier 😄 . thanks!

Would it be an option to write it to the server logs?

When I had the issue, I checked the browser console on the network tab and server logs, but couldn't find any information about the error.
I also checked elasticsearch errors, but also didn't see any error (this could of course be my configuration).

title: CommandPalette: Improve section header styling

commits_data.message: Add border between command palette sections

comments_data.body:
Not in love with how i did this, but totally open to better suggestions!

I tried using a distinct `<hr />`-ish element for the border, but it ended up just as fiddly to get the padding right.

The only alternative I can find is to play around with margin and padding... This css achieves the same with only a `sectionHeader` (no `sectionHeaderInner`), but I think it might be _more_ hacky:
```
  sectionHeader: css({
    fontSize: theme.typography.h6.fontSize,
    fontWeight: theme.typography.body.fontWeight,
    color: theme.colors.text.secondary,
    padding: theme.spacing(1, 2, 3),
    borderTop: `1px solid ${theme.colors.border.medium}`,
    marginTop: theme.spacing(2),
  }),
```
When I used margin the elements would be positioned in the virtualised list, and so it would look all wonky…
Yeah I had to very hackily add bottom padding to make up for the margin not counting for the height of the item 👀  Ill approve this PR, I think your solution is the best one

comments_data.body: this is the source of the type issues, because this allowed all enum values for TableCellDisplayMode it completely breaks the union type and Typescripts ability to use this property as a descriminator

here you can see an example of Typescript union+descriminator typing working, cellOptions.mode is here fully typed automatically because it's inside the if statement of cellOptions.type === TableCellDisplayMode.ColorBackground
Ah I see, I definitely misunderstood how that would work in practice and it seemed like this _should_ work. That's clearly not the case though 🤦

Thanks for pointing this out! I had actually gotten a bit confused because my editor didn't seem to be picking up the types here. However, my editor has been somewhat flaky with type checking so I attributed it to that. Shot myself in the foot with this one 😔

Seems like a bit of bummer to lose typing here, probably worth a follow up but I think the select can be directly changed to work with `TableCellOptions` instead of just the type. 

I was able to get typescript to not complain using these types:

```typescript
interface CellDisplayModeOption {
  value: TableCellOptions;
  label: string
}

const cellDisplayModeOptions: CellDisplayModeOption[] = [
  { value: { type: TableCellDisplayMode.Auto } , label: 'Auto' },
  { value: { type: TableCellDisplayMode.ColorText }, label: 'Colored text' },
  { value: { type: TableCellDisplayMode.ColorBackground }, label: 'Colored background' },
  { value: { type: TableCellDisplayMode.Gauge }, label: 'Gauge' },
  { value: { type: TableCellDisplayMode.JSONView }, label: 'JSON View' },
  { value: { type: TableCellDisplayMode.Image }, label: 'Image' },
];
```

Don't think that should prevent merging this but perhaps worth following up with.
Have a few (very) nitpicky things, there's an extra `/` here
Extra white space here
Also an unnecessary `/` here

This is a bit of a shame here as well. I think these are being caused by the backwards compatibility of TableCellDisplayMode which still support old values even though the type TableCellOptions type can't possibly be those values.

I'm not sure if it's worth investing time for this though.
yea, that could work.
yea, this one it the trickiest as we dont have typed schema for old / invalid values

title: Auth: Add skip_org_role_sync setting to OAuth integration Google

commits_data.message:
Add: skip_org_role_sync for Google OAuth

- add setting for frontend
- add read of config
- add config to sample and default

Apply suggestions from code review

Co-authored-by: Christopher Moyer <35463610+chri2547@users.noreply.github.com>

comments_data.body:
```suggestion
```

As we do not get roles from Google auth provider.

Here is the setting that we set eventually after the code goes through a user that logs in without a role assigned from the provider.
https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/main/pkg/services/user/userimpl/user.go#L151

```suggestion
| Google | false | false | User organization roles are set with `defaultRole` and cannot be changed |
```

```suggestion
| Google | true | false | User organization roles are set with `defaultRole` for Google. For other providers, the synchronization will be skipped, and the org role can be changed, along with other OAuth provider users' org roles. |
```

```suggestion
| Google | false | true | User organization roles are set with `defaultRole` and the org role can be changed for Google synced users. |
```

```suggestion
| Google | true | true | User organization roles are set with `defaultRole` for Google. For other providers, the synchronization will be skipped, and the org role can be changed, along with other OAuth provider users' org roles. |
```

```suggestion
We do not currently sync roles from Google and instead set the AutoAssigned role to the user at first login. To manage your user's organization role from within Grafana, set `skip_org_role_sync` to `true`.
```

```suggestion
Upon the first login from a user, we set the organization roles from the setting `AutoAssignOrgRole`. If you want to manage organizational roles, set the `skip_org_role_sync` option to `true`. 

> **Note:** There is a separate setting called `oauth_skip_org_role_update_sync` which has a different scope. While `skip_org_role_sync` only applies to the specific OAuth provider, `oauth_skip_org_role_update_sync` is a generic setting that affects all configured OAuth providers.
```

```suggestion
The following table shows the OAuth provider's setting with the default value and the skip org role sync setting.
```

```suggestion
The following table shows the OAuth provider's setting with the default value and the skip org role sync setting.
```
nit: should this be a part of the above note?

yea, it is a bit verbose currently. I want to review the docs at some point soon, to either make it more concise or to put all the tables together of sorts.

comments_data.body:
I don't think this should be `Error`
```suggestion
	logger.Debug("pushing streams", "streams", streams)
```
I just removed it entirely. It logs the full structs, which is also bad.
rule is accepted here but not used.

nit:

when I see the word build it reminds me of the [builder pattern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Builder_pattern) which I think this is not it.

A common idiom is to name these functions that do "type conversation" like `alertsToStreams`
nit: Do not have constants for these labels? They seem key enough to warrant their own.

nit: I don't think this is worth the indirection - having the ability to see what you're converting this to seems pretty simple. In particular, because you've extracted the irrelevant in `buildDataBlob` which I do agree warrant its own functions.
I'm surprised not to see a unit test for this function. Will these come later?

`state.State` already has a [string representation](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/main/pkg/services/ngalert/eval/eval.go#L218-L220)

Have you considered?

```suggestion
		jsonData.Set(fmt.Sprint(state), true)
```
nit: Can we realistically expect anything here? I'd consider changing to message to convey that you received an empty response.

Yes, and we expect this bit of the format will change. I don't like it as-is, it's hard to write LogQL around, we have a separate task to nail this one down.

This function is literally copy-pasted from the annotations implementation and renamed (with some deletion of things we didn't care about). That's why no tests for now - this is more about getting something to appear.
Good catch, it used to be but that got factored out!
Applied a similar pattern to `buildDataBlob`

1. Copy-pasted from annotations and this will change.
2. It's a JSON field, and this uses JSON-friendly casing for keys.
3. We aren't necessarily just using the state as the key here. For most states, the key is the string `"values"`. This field only _happens_ to have similar wording to a state.
Also logging the status code now, too.
Sure, inlined

title: Datasources: Fix Proxy by UID Failing for UIDs with a Hyphen

commits_data.message:
Fix Proxy by UID Failing for UIDs with a Hyphen

Hyphens are allowed in short IDs but not picked up by the
proxyPathRegexp. This caused the end of the uid to be proxied as part of
the path to the backing datasource which would usually cause a 404.

comments_data.body: if you like to return the errors from all the clients instead, then you could consider using [go-multierror](https://pkg.go.dev/github.com/hashicorp/go-multierror#Append).
How would they play with errutil.Error?
I guess it would unwrap to the first one
good questions, let me try it

the following test succeeds for me:
```
func TestMultierror(t *testing.T) {
	errInternal := NewBase(StatusInternal,
		"just.testing.internal", WithPublicMessage("internal error"))

	errUnauthorised := NewBase(StatusUnauthorized,
		"just.testing.unauthorised", WithPublicMessage("unauthorised"))

	var result error

	result = multierror.Append(result, errInternal.Errorf("err1"))
	result = multierror.Append(result, errUnauthorised.Errorf("err2"))

	assert.ErrorIs(t, result, errInternal)
	assert.ErrorIs(t, result, errUnauthorised)
	assert.Equal(t, result.Error(), "2 errors occurred:\n\t* [just.testing.internal] err1\n\t* [just.testing.unauthorised] err2\n\n")
}
```

but I would like to know also what @sakjur thinks
Yeah It works, but when using error.As it seems to unwrap to the first one of the type you are targeting. And that is ok :)

```suggestion
func (q *queue[T]) insert(c T, priority int) {
```

maybe we can use it with `any` and without the priority method (defining the priority when we register them) so we can use this for post auth hooks as well?

comments_data.body: Should we check if the error message is within the panel status wrapper?
Are we sure of this behavior? For me, if the indicator represents the status of the query, and it is errored, I'd show the indicator anyway to give as much as possible information to the user.

Is this backward compatibility? Do we plan to deprecate the title? I think we agreed on the title property should be present. So it is not backward compatibility if the API is still the same after the new panel chrome. wdyt?
Do we call things wrappers by default? Why don't we call it just `panel-loading-indicator` and only represent semantically the object, not reflecting its internal layout of it?

Yes, the previous functionality of when we show the error of the data in a panel covered only the case when we have a message, did not rely on the `data.state` prop at all. This is because the error can be coming from more than one place, i.e. [here](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/polibb/panel-tests/public/app/features/dashboard/dashgrid/PanelStateWrapper.tsx#L295) and [here](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/polibb/panel-tests/public/app/features/dashboard/dashgrid/PanelStateWrapper.tsx#L367). 

We can look into that, if there's a better way, but for now we're covering the functionality as it is before the new designs.

The `title` is an optional prop and as far as I know it will continue to be. We did mention something about making it mandatory for specific types of panels (hovering header was it?), but I don't think we made a decision to do so. 
The idea of the new API is to always rely on the prop `hoverHeader` to decide if we have a header or not. Regardless of the presence of any or all other props.

I'm not sure. The `PanelStatus` rendered inside the `panel-status-wrapper` div is its own component, we don't technically know what it is doing with the message. Then the `PanelStatus` renders a `ToolbarButton`, so for me it is responsibility of the `ToolbarButton` to have unit tests to prove that it is rendering whatever content is given to it in the expected format and place.

You are right, we don't need to semantically represent explicitly what the arrangement is, just if the required object is there. In general I prefer not to use `data-testid`, but `div` and `span` components are "invisible" to RTL selectors. 
On another note, this loading bar is not checked correctly anyway - the condition is after the wrapper. I'm changing to have custom aria-label and look for the label in the tests :)
Regardless of the  `statusMessage` presence, we should show the status when the loading state is Error. Otherwise user will see errored panel, but will not be aware of that.

I understand your point of view, I used to think that's the way to go as well. @torkelo changed the implementation [in a follow-up PR here](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/61595/commits/5f36a3c714a0543faa764f8baa88068952b6850d) (lines 106 and 152), so I looked into it then and I noticed then that this is indeed what the current functionality of showing the error is: [panel header corner error](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/polibb/panel-tests/public/app/features/dashboard/dashgrid/PanelHeader/PanelHeaderCorner.tsx#L98)

I think from the point of view of `PanelChrome`, it receives a `loadingState` that can be one of `'NotStarted' | 'Loading' | 'Streaming' | 'Done' | 'Error'`, so currently there's a distinction between 'Not Started', 'Done', and 'Error'. If we ignore 'Error' we are saying that all three have the same response on the UI of PanelChrome.

Moreover, right now only `statusMessage` shows the errored status and `statusMessageOnClick` does not have that power. It seems to me a valid case to have an error and see no immediate message, but to be able to click on it to trigger an action that will show you something more/take you somewhere else. (We have a default message 'Error in plugin', but that doesn't mean everyone would)

Hence, I would allow the user to see _the errored sign_ if `loadingState is 'Error'`, if there is a `statusMessage`, **or** if there is a `statusMessageOnClick`. Or maybe **only** rely on the loadingState and leave for the dev to set up statusMessage and statusMessageOnClick if they have use of them?

Those are my thoughts atm.

IMO having a panel in an erroneous state without showing any indication is a bad, confusing UX.

Can't we have a default status message, like "Something went wrong...." to show when the state is error?

I like @dprokop idea. IMO:

There is a single status for a panel: `loading | error | streaming | done | etc`. But it is composed of two props: `loadingState` and `statusMessage`.  The status message is contextual information about the current status. I can imagine the future having `LoadingStatus.Warning` and having the status message as well. In this case, the status would be a warning.

So, IMO I wouldn't ignore the LoadingState in any case and default to a generic message if it is not provided.

> We did mention something about making it mandatory for specific types of panels (hovering header was it?)

No, sorry. It should be optional, you're right.

> The idea of the new API is to always rely on the prop hoverHeader to decide if we have a header or not. 

Ok, I understand, ignore my comment then :)

Okay. I wasn't sure a default message on PanelChrome's part is a good idea, but it does make sense in the context that there is an indicator when there's an error, but one wouldn't necessarily know which indicator that is 😊🙏.

@torkelo what do you think?

I think everyone is very confused 

Let's have different props control different things, ok? loadingState => controls loading animation, statusMessage controls statusMessage. To me, this seems so much easier from the consumer's (developer) point of view for this component

I think it would be fine if the panel showed a red border or something via LoadingState.Error, then the prop would control that aspect (loading border animation, streaming state, error border). but let's not conflate it with the statusMessage. I think that should only be set with the statusMessage prop. Very easy for the consumer of the component to then control when and how the statusMessage is shown.

Okay 🙌, statusMessage adds a status icon with a message on the header, and if we one day have an indicator that the loadingState holds 'Error' it will be a separate concern. 

With this in mind, this PR has no need for further changes.

title: Auth: Add skip_org_role_sync setting for github

commits_data.message:
Add: tests for allowGrafanaAdmin

- both for the case when both settings are set and the setting for only
  allowGrafanaAdmin

Apply suggestions from code review

Co-authored-by: Christopher Moyer <35463610+chri2547@users.noreply.github.com>

comments_data.body:
I think currently you would always set Grafana server admin role to false if Github `skipOrgRoleSync` and `allowAssignGrafanaAdmin` are both enabled. It's a bit of a weird config setup, but I think we'd want to skip syncing server admin role in that case, right?

So you probably want to set `IsGrafanaAdmin` to `nil` if Github `skipOrgRoleSync` is enabled to avoid syncing that role. 

It would also be good to have tests covering server admin.
nit: import ordering - move the external `"golang.org/x/oauth2"` import above the internal dependency and add an empty line.
nice! thx

title: Alerting: Create query interface for state history along with annotation-based implementation

commits_data.message: Define querier interface and return an empty dataframe
Create an implementation of QueryHistory for annotations
Perform rule lookup and add a simple smoke-test

comments_data.body:
The rest of this file maps the query interface onto annotations, as best it can. We error or warn if a query attempts to use a query feature that annotations do not fundamentally support.

This logic isn't used by anything currently, and is meant to be more of a reference implementation. We expect it will change over time as the query interface is implemented for the other backend types.

The interface itself is the main focus of this PR - review that first and foremost. Shortcomings in the annotation implementation will change over time as we flesh out the endpoint.

In order for the interface to have a valid implementation, we need **some** way of mapping the annotations into a dataframe.

The approach used here is a very naive one, that really only works for annotations as it only supports a single series generated by a single rule. We have a separate task (see epic) to create a more permanent mapping, which will be done in the future. The goal here is only get _something_ to show up, in dataframe format.
This is easy to extend with more filters. For things like Loki, the user also has the ability to query Loki directly and get arbitrary query power.


So this is a little nuanced, but you can't leverage a data source without a plugin. This makes it seem that plugins do something "extra" to data sources. 

Perhaps:
You can enable data sources by installing and configuring their associated Grafana plugins. For a list of available plugins, see  **link**. Alternatively, you can create your own, custom plugin. To learn more refer to **link**.

(I have a personal vendetta against unintroduced hyperlinks—feel free to ignore that)

```suggestion

```

Hmm maybe I misunderstand. I thought Grafana had two models to use data sources:

- Built-in support. These ship with the Grafana binary, and they do not need to be installed.
- Extended through plugins. These have to be added from the available plugin list, or custom built.

Am I off here? I see that in some instances, the Grafana site says "plugin" to mean built-in data source.

> Loki Data Source - Native Plugin
> This is a built in data source that allows you to connect to the Loki logging service. [^1]

In my opinion, Grafana should avoid calling things that ship with the base binary a "plugin". I worry that this could corrode associations of meaning in the reader's heads, since, as far as I'm aware, plugin typically means an optional component to add to the system. It implies some customizability and tells people who don't want to use this data source that they can keep their binary footprint lighter by not installing it.

To call Loki a plugin implies that it could be plugged out, but that's not really true―it'd be more like rewiring.

I think saying things like "supported data source" or "built-in support" reduces cognitive reader load. To use _plugin_ to mean "outside of the base binary" creates a clear distinction. This is all to say that, if I haven't missed something, I'd prefer to try to reduce terms like "native plugin" in other places rather than introduce them here.

Does that make sense?

[^1]: https://grafana.com/grafana/plugins/loki/

> This makes it seem that plugins do something "extra" to data sources.

I see your point about this sentence, though. What about this?

```diff
- You can also extend the supported data sources through one of the many [Plugins]
+ You can also add more data sources with Plugins
```

@Eve832 what do you think?  (ignoring the hyperlink―that's not a big deal to me).
There are only like 13 data sources that we natively support (fewer in Cloud I think). There are 80+ data sources. All of those not natively supported require a plugin

> There are only like 13 data sources that we natively support (fewer in Cloud I think). There are 80+ data sources. All of those not natively supported require a plugin

```
Grafana comes with built-in support for many _data sources_.
If you need other data sources, you can also install one of the many data source plugins.
If the plugin you need doesn't exist, you can also create your own custom plugin. 

Each data source comes with a _query editor_,
which formulates custom queries according to the source's particular structure.
After you add a data source, you can use it as an input for many operations:
- Query the data with [Explore]({{< relref "../explore" >}}).
- Visualize it in [panels]({{< relref "../panels-visualizations" >}}).
- Create rules for [alerts]({{< relref "../alerting" >}}).

This documentation goes over how to manage data sources in general,
and how to configure or query the built-in data sources.
For other data sources, refer to the list of [datasource plugins](/grafana/plugins/).
To make a custom plugin, refer to [Build a plugin]({{< relref "../developers/plugins/" >}}).
```

title: Draft/error state

comments_data.body: hey @idastambuk is your proposal to add `if (state !== LoadingState.Loading && error) {` And the runRequest change below, or is this OR that?
It's either or! I updated the description to be more clear. I like the second solution better, but if we need the error object there for some reason, the first one fixes the problem too

> Hey @idastambuk I think the thing I'm missing here is why the loading state never resolves the second time around? I think it's a fair question whether or not we clear an error when we make the request the second time around or when we get a non-errored response, but I think regardless it feels like we should get the loading/not loading state passed down to us in someway, and I think I'm missing where that happens/doesn't happen, you know?

Definitely. The explanation is a bit long but: the reason we dont clear the loading state the second time around has to do with the RunQueryButtons component in Redshift, which keeps 2 internal loading states ("cancelling" and "running" query) and updates them according to the LoadingState it gets from the panel. 

In this case, however, the state is kept in LoadingState.Error (because of the above logic) and the component never triggers the useEffect that tells it to stop loading. 

The place where the error state is persisted is just before where QueryEditor is being imported, in  QueryGroupRow: 

```
if (error) {
    state = LoadingState.Error; //so even if there's a loading state, if the error is truthy, it will overwrite it

```

If it gets a different response, like Success, it will update. Meaning the only use case where this bug appears is if there are two errors in a row. AND if any of the plugin components depend on this loading state. Which they do when they implement long-running features. (The same thing happens in Athena.) 

Of course then it might be said: Why are we fixing it in Grafana repo and not the buttons component, but even if we want to fix it and only depend on the state from the panel, we need the correct state actually passed down (as you said)

Ah ok so I think this is starting to make sense to me! Going to repeat it back and you can correct me if I'm wrong:
- we currently override the loading state in this file to "Error" whenever we encounter an error
- we always encounter an error if the last request had an error when we "preProcessPanelData" below we never remove old errors from the panel data, we simply keep whatever lastResult was. 

- We we decide to fix "preProcessPanelData" to clear out old errors we will get up to date loading state data. However we may cause other datasources to be a bit "jumpy" if a user refreshes a broken query and gets an error, clears it out, and then gets the same error popping up again
- An alternative to this jumpy behavior is to not override the state here to an error state when we are still loading. The pros are that this would not cause jumpy-ness, the cons are that we wouldn't know we were in a loading state until all the queries had finished getting called.

Does that sound right? Definitely seems worth talking about with other developers outside of team to get their thoughts! I think I can see an argument either way. I think I would lean towards fixing it here in QueryEditorRow so that we pass along the loading state and don't manually override to error until loading is done. It seems less disruptive maybe? But I would be curious to see what others think!

I am still unclear why this has only become an issue after releasing long running queries, it feels like this would have existed for lots of datasources? Even when we didn't have a run query button in the query editor we still have it outside? Maybe we do weird logic to handle it there?

You got it, all's correct except the last point where 
`
the cons are that we wouldn't know we were in a loading state until all the queries had finished getting called.
`

The loading state will actually be propagated in this case (if we add a !== LoadingState.Loading, since the state won't be overwritten. So this solution, to just add a condition in the QueryEditorRow would, for the end user, be seamless. 
I agree it would also be (much) less risky, as we still don't know why the error state is being persisted from lastResult. If we don't get a reply from someone that knows the ins and outs of this, this will probably be the final solution. 

This is why I wanted peoples' opinions, as it still feels like a half-measure (and possibly might cause other unintended behavior in the future?)

To answer your last question about why the problem is noticeable only now, if you look at the RunQueryButtons in async-query-data repo, there is some logic that controls the loading buttons based on this state. We dont have the same logic in other datasources, but my theory is that other datasources with a button in the header (even though there isn't a lot of consistency in how querying UX is so it's hard to tell) wouldn't display this Loading state either. I haven't managed to reproduce the same conditions, but I will come up with something tomorrow.

title: AzureMonitor: Move DefaultSubscriptions field to separate component

commits_data.message:
Move DefaultSubscriptions field to separate component

- Add separate component
- Update CredentialsForm
- Update tests
- Remove redundant test

Remove defaultSubscriptionId

- Update MonitorConfig to appropriately set subscriptionId
- Update DefaultSubscription component to make use of JsonData
- Remove references to defaultSubscriptionId
- Update tests
- Update mockInstanceSettings for flexibility

Review

- Add DefaultSubscription test and remove component from AzureCredentialsForm test
- Remove onCredentialsChange from DefaultSubscription
- Set subscription as a part of onSubscriptionChange

comments_data.body:
Could you please completely decouple the subscription from credentials?

Default subscription is just a field `subscriptionId` in JsonData. We need to remove it from `AzureCredentialsBase` ([here](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/e8c2091537a0641d71c3790ec88b5ae34da57bc6/public/app/plugins/datasource/grafana-azure-monitor-datasource/types/types.ts#L38)), to make the interface look the same as it defined in ADX ([here](https://github.com/grafana/azure-data-explorer-datasource/blob/42176219a831d41fc1e1999617e4686d43ca8b84/src/components/ConfigEditor/AzureCredentials.ts#L19)).
I agree this makes sense. It could be a breaking change so some migration code may be needed.
Data schema should not change. The field `subscriptionId` stays unchanged. `AzureCredentialsBase` is in-memory only, so changing it should not require any migration.

This still keeps coupling between credentials and default subscription.
There's no need to save `subscriptionId` via `updateCredentials`.

The `DefaultSubscription` may call the `onSubscriptionChanged` callback with `subscriptionId` and then `MonitorConfig` could just update JsonData using `updateOptions` method.
`DefaultSubscription` doesn't have to be a child of `AzureCredentialsForm`. They can be adjacent controls managed by the `MonitorConfig` parent control.

We will need to separate the `DefaultSubscription` control form `AzureCredentialsForm.test.tsx` to be able to move  `AzureCredentialsForm.test.tsx` to a shared library. Is it possible to make the `DefaultSubscription` adjacent rather than a child?
I've looked into this for the past few Grafana versions and this should not be a breaking change 😊

`DefaultSubscripton` doesn't actually need to know anything about credentials.

In my opinion, it could be implemented with only three main properties:
- `subscriptions` - the list of subscriptions to select from (supplied from outside and empty if not yet loaded)
- `subscriptionId` \ `selectedSubscription` - the subscription which was actually selected, `undefined` if no subscription has been selected.
- `onSubscriptionChange` - callback when another subscription being selected, so the outside code, `MonitorConfig` can apply it to datasource settings.

Every time `AzureCredentialsForm` changes credentials, it calls` onCredentialsChange` and `MonitorConfig` clears the `subscriptions` state variable which would propagate to the `DefaultSubscription` control.

`MonitorConfig` could also be responsible for the asynchronous call to fetch the list of subscriptions since it knows when credentials change and knows when to re-fetch the subscriptions.
I can separate this component from the test 👍🏽
I've updated this function to remove the `subscriptionId` dependency.

comments_data.body:
Can we just remove this randomness? It makes this test an absolute nightmare to read. Is it trying to test when a subset of the alerts are ProvenanceNone? What happens when none of them are? All of them are? This took me multiple read-throughs to understand what property it's trying to assert about the system.

Also, it appears from the name, it's not testing the right thing, intermittently.

The test's name suggests that it's intentionally trying to test when a few of the rules have ProvenanceNone, and others have some provenance. But, if the `rand.Intn()` call is zero, none of them have provenance, so it's not really testing anything! This could let an actual issue through the CI, a small fraction of the time. Let's just drop the randomness entirely.
This test tests exactly what is declared: that the method returns false when the provenance map either does not contain any UID of the provided rules or all rules have provenanceNone in the map.

I asked around and the possibility of the value being zero is intentional. I confirmed this by hardcoding a `0` and running the test.

I agree on the legibility thing, it took me a while to figure out what this test was about. This could be separated in two different tests:
1. No rules with provisioning info.
3. Some rules w/o info, some rules with `ProvenanceNone`.

This way we'd eliminate the randomness while having the same scenarios being tested.
+1 for different tests

title: Schema: Move known shared types into the common

commits_data.message: Rexport dupliate types to fix errors

comments_data.body: @sdboyer generating types for this file fails with error `failed to generate common schema TS: could not generate field: %!w(*errors.posError=&{{0xc001125180 19732} [] {bottom, unsatisfiable []}})`, started happening after I've added `@cuetsy(kind="interface")` to the types. Any idea what could it be?
Looks like comments on enum fields don't work as they are not present in the generated types.
Generating this fails without providing `memberNames`, looks like an issue with enum keys that contain dashes.
I think this is probably something we could improve in cuetsy's default enum member name extraction behavior - treat dashes as word separators and capitalize the following letter.
Oof. No, no immediate ideas on that one. i'll have to debug.

Let's default to not using definitions for now
```suggestion
Field: {
```

i have the feeling it might be better to avoid moving these types at all without first checking with folks like @kylebrandt - is there a particular known case within plugins that led you to move these dataframe-related ones?
Found the issue, looks like having a separate type with a single value doesn't work, e.g. `#DecimalCount?: int64 @cuetsy(kind="type")`.
Saw it used in the [dashboard datasource](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/main/public/app/plugins/datasource/dashboard/types.ts#L1), but not sure how important that is.

I think I would need more of the larger context to understand. Is the goal here to use cue just for typescript and the frontend, or do we want to be generating the Go types that go with `data.Frame` (field, etc) as well?

If it is the case we are going for the Go types as well, I think this is going to be hard one. Currently the frame code and libraries live in another repo, https://github.com/grafana/grafana-plugin-sdk-go/tree/main/data (and this library is imported by virtually every data source). This is also a place we want a tight binding, and is also generally performance sensitive.

So perhaps continue for the sake of exploration (to learn just what the set of issues will be for end-to-end type gen and binding here, but maybe won't be mergable for some time)? Also perhaps limit to just FrameMeta? I expect that is easier.

Maybe @ryantxu has thoughts?

@sdboyer I've tried moving these duplicate types into `common_dataquery.cue` but they still end up in `common.gen.ts`, any idea how to make them available in cue but do not include in generated files, since these types are already present in dashboard types?
i thiiiink if you just omit the `@cuetsy` attributes on them, it should do what you want?

> Currently the frame code and libraries live in another repo, https://github.com/grafana/grafana-plugin-sdk-go/tree/main/data (and this library is imported by virtually every data source). This is also a place we want a tight binding

Tight binding meaning, careful control over when these types change and keeping things in sync, right? That's been my assumption to date, and why i've assumed there would be a couple additional steps before we could bring these into canonical schema systems.

But yes, at some point in the medium-term future, it looks like we'll need to find adequate answers to the sync and performance questions so that we can incorporate these into SSoT

> Tight binding meaning, careful control over when these types change and keeping things in sync, right?

Yup! So a great candidate for bring things together - but a harder one perhaps.
But then they will be just generated inline and not available for use in other cue files?
I'll leave the schema for DataFrame here, in case anyone will want to continue working on it in the future.
Had to do these re-exports for the duplicated types to resolve type issues.
The formatting looks a bit off on some of the fields, but it looks fine in my EDI, so not sure what's the issue here.
Not sure about this one. `Vector` is actually an interface with a lot of methods, so not really serialisable.

> but a harder one perhaps.

Could be. For now, i don't see a significant difference vs. what we have to implement with grok - synchronization from the SSoT in grafana out to a second repo on a release-tied cadence. We've got a decent plan in place for that (cc @malcolmholmes) for grok, and my handwavy expectation has been to reuse as much of we can of that approach in the plugin sdk.

oh. yeah. 🤦🏻 

will have to think on these a bit

This will be super interesting to see what we land with, but note that is is a BIG project that is already actively used by every backend plugin and most frontend plugins.  The handwavy generation logic will likely need to generate exactly what exists (or very close with clear depreciation path) before it is useable directly.

But yes conceptually it is the same (actually simpler than) dashbaords
This should only ever exist in a runtime context -- I am not sure we want it to cross into schema land, or do we have a clear way to say it should never be serialized?
given how big the potential data_frame/meta issue will be, can this be its own project/PR?

the DataFrame interface as is is explicitly not serializable (directly) originally it was apache arrow, but I think we can/should remove the interface, it will require something like https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/38615

cc @leeoniya -- that is something we should consider for 10, but as is the `DataFrame` type in both frontend+backend do not correspond to implementations that thema will generate easily.  (Totally possible, but a bigger project). The metadata side is much more approachable.

> as is the DataFrame type in both frontend+backend do not correspond to implementations that thema will generate easily

_resists the urge to "CHALLENGE ACCEPTED!"_ 😉 

It sounds like there are specific, known concerns here? AFAIK our only real issue atm is with recursive TS types. Discriminated unions aren't really an issue anymore, given TS veneers

yeah, we were hoping to get a bunch of these in so that others didn't have to do it when they organically ran into them while schematizing on Wednesday. But there are non-obvious considerations here - we'll need to take these in steps. Which is OK!
Yeah, ok, I'll move it to a separate PR since those types aren't 100% usable in the current state anyways.

title: Add handleGrafanaManagedAlerts jsonData

comments_data.body:
```suggestion
If you are provisioning your data source, set the flag `handleGrafanaManagedAlerts` in the `jsonData` field to `true` to send Grafana-managed alerts to this Alertmanager.
```

I think this info belongs here more than on this page? of course we can add it to both for more visibility; but this topic is the concept -- this topic is how to add an external alertmanager: https://grafana.com/docs/grafana/latest/alerting/set-up/configure-alertmanager/
wdyt?

comments_data.body: This is because I do not want to change the type name in many places
We have to move this file into `models`. Originally it is being created in the root folder of the plugin. Being inside the root folder causes circular dependency issues

This is just a dummy converter method. I think codegen should provide such functionality. Not for each generated file of course but a more centralized solution. i.e. https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/blob/main/aws/to_ptr.go

nil checks are not nice but for now if we have optional parameters we have to have pointers. we have to get rid of some optional but eventually we will have some. There must be a better way to deal with nil checks.
This is the nicest way that we came up with to prevent ugly nested if-else blocks :)

Here the package name was generated wrong. It was in the `prometheus` folder and should be `prometheus` but it was something else. Also when we run `make run` it was generated again. So even we change it manually it will be overwritten. So to see the result we have to comment out the codegen step in `Makefile`
hmmm, this shouldn't be the case anymore - I moved the generator to point to a subdirectory called `kinds` to deal with the circular dependency issue
agreed! 👍
Same happened for the [Cloudwatch go](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/61770/files#diff-24241a55ac221e0692e3a4dc9335ed3d41a6fa3236e886cc2ae1fa9ed1ac43d9) files.

in general, CUE does give more nuanced control over values, optionality and defaults than Go. Once we put its unmarshaler in place here, there will be less ambiguity in the values that appear in your Go structs.
ok clearly that change didn't make it into the overall batch of changes in the unification PR. will change that before schema day 😊

> Here the package name was generated wrong. It was in the prometheus folder and should be prometheus but it was something else.

Yeah, i noticed this when fixing the file location issue. Also fixing that in the same PR.

> Also when we run make run it was generated again. So even we change it manually it will be overwritten.

This is by design. In order for schemas to actually, meaningfully be a single source of truth, they must all be regenerated on every `make gen-cue` execution, and the generated types must be used as-is, without any direct edits to the generated file. (Logical transformations of the generated type are fine, though can clearly get into risky territory. That's what the veneers system are all about.)

This is a strict rule, and if there's a problem with how the code generators work that prevents you from being able to follow it, that's key for us to know so we can fix the issue (as i have with these issues in #61899)! However, we can't say that a kind has advanced to `experimental` maturity until this standard is met, which means it won't show up for use in as-code contexts.

what is the thought on where the runtime things should live?  requestId/interval/intervalMs are not valid when saved in panel JSON, but are required/always present when making a request to the backend

> are not valid

you're saying that it would be incorrect to include them, because that's ephemeral data, correct?

Yes, what's included in schematized types should ultimately be limited to persisted data, and specifically not include ephemeral data that exists only in the context of a particular request. I'll update our guide accordingly.

There are reasonably straightforward answers here; the main question is whether the additional ephemeral fields are determined by the system, or by the plugin.
provided in #61948

right -- they are ephemeral and should never be saved as input to queries

The `DataQuery` in the backend has similar properties, but does have a section that is system defined.  These particular properties are added original by the system (PanelQueryRunner) and then the datasource adds the properties to each query
I am pretty sure these are runtime values filled in from the dashboard, right?
yep, PR (and guide docs) are now updated to indicate that only persisted data should be included - an oversight
Goland was showing me red lines on `grafana-plugin-sdk-go` so I run `go mod tidy` and had this. I am not sure if that is ok.
@grafana/observability-metrics As a second step we should check and decide which one should be optional and which one should be required.
you need to rerun "make gen-cue" I think
you need to rerun "make gen-cue" I think
might be worth checking why it is better here and not in the .cue, as backend seems to also make use of this one

Yes, having a discussion about what is optional and required would be helpful. As I have worked on migrations to React in other datasources, a number of fields have been added to the dataquery model to handle the migration, and all of these are optional. The most important field is `expr` and everything else is feature based, but it would help to go through all of these one by one and confirm that.
range, interval, intervalMs, and expr
do we want "*string" -- rather than just string?  using "" as indication of missing (just like omitempty)
We should make sure that only values that can be set by the user exist in this schema.  I am pretty sure interval + intervalMs are added based on the dashboard view
It is interesting that this is just a static calculation from the start/end times already passed in the query -- perhaps we should just calculate on the backend?

@ryantxu I want to check this after merging this PR since it is outside of the scope of this PR. But you are absolutely right. I will see if there is a reason behind this calculation being done on the frontend
@ryantxu I do not fully understand your point here. Can you elaborate on it, please?

title: Datasources: Use getDefaultQuery in annotations editors

commits_data.message: Dont pass CoreApp to annotation query

comments_data.body: i'm not sure if running `getDefaultQuery` is necessary here. wouldn't the query already have the defaults applied when creating a new annotation query?
what is the reason for removing `queryIsEmpty`?

It wasn't really doing anything, since 
1. if fields returned from getDefaultQuery will be overwritten by "t" anyway
2. if the getDefaultQuery method is undefined, it will just return the "t" anyway.

I can see why it would be expected to have the defaults applied, yes. However, the defaults are applied only in the render() method in StandardAnnotationQueryEditor, after which the onChange isn't called. This is why it has to be applied here too, since if you run "test query" right after mount, it won't have the default values. I don't love the solution, especially if it's confusing to someone else seeing it. 
However, I haven't found a good place to do it: 
1. It can be left to the datasource devs to do it prepareAnnotation method in each datasource, but this seems a bit hidden, somehow?
2. Related to that, I could do it in verifyDatasource before prepareAnnotation is called, but neither runs when changing datasource (so it cant update with default values), only when changing the query. Not sure why, as I would expect it to, but it's due to how the code is structured and changing it isn't in the scope of this PR. But if you think it should be done before this is merged, let me know and we can check it out!

i see. i think it would be worth looking into seeing if it could be run somehow during `verifyDatasource`. looks like it's called on mount and updates so should cover initial render and changing datasources.
nit: add a newline above this
I agree, it's worth looking into. Will merge this now, but I will schedule a time to take a look at why componentDidUpdate doesn't trigger the verifyDatasource on datasource change

title: test PR 61471

commits_data.message:
Look for 'caused_by.reason' in ES error response

When the ES response does not contain `reason` or `root_cause[0].reason`
is empty, there is no information for the user to know what is going
wrong.

An example of the error message after this change:
```
Failed to evaluate queries and expressions: failed to execute query A: Trying to create too many buckets. Must be less than or equal to: [65536] but this number of buckets was exceeded. This limit can be set by changing the [search.max_buckets] cluster level setting.
```

Related to https://github.com/grafana/grafana/issues/61246

comments_data.body:
Rather than having this conditional statement, how do we all feel about taking this opportunity to clone also this component into their separate components for Loki/Prom?
@grafana/observability-logs @grafana/observability-metrics

Hm, I feel the `50000` value is a bit "hidden" here in CSS. What do you think about introducing a const somewhere more prominent?

Also, before merging, I feel we should be sure that 50000 is a "good" number to start with.
What do we do if this request fails, i.e. in case of an older Loki version?

I think we should rather use something like https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/main/public/app/plugins/datasource/loki/modifyQuery.ts#L142 to get the correct matcher. 

Btw, how do we use this endpoint for queries with multiple stream selectors? As "easiest" something like `rate({foo="bar"}[5m]) + rate({foo="baz"}[5m])`

Instead of this `as` assignment, you can also add a generic to the `fetch` call: 

```
getBackendSrv().fetch<QueryStats>()
```

I think we can move this to the `LokiQueryBuilderOptions` component, since `query` is already part of the properties. This would also take away the bad sideeffect, that `onChange(query);` is executed after the `/stats` call returned. Which potentially slows things down by a lot.
this makes sense! also disabled the colour change for now until find the best way to calculate the threshold, as discussed in standup.

@svennergr there are two possible ways for this to fail.

**First:**
the user is using a version that supports this endpoint, however they are not configured to use `tsdb`.
in this case we still make the request but loki will always return `{ streams: 0, chunks: 0, bytes: 0, entries: 0 }`. 
we have a check to catch this and if the value of `queryStats.bytes` is falsy we just don’t display the tooltip.

**Second:**
the user is using a version of loki where this endpoint is not supported
in this case loki returns a 404 so `queryStats.bytes` is falsy, meaning it it caught by the same logic as above and the tooltip is not displayed.

this was the easiest solution as we have no way to detect the loki version being used (from my knowledge, correct me if i am wrong).

I don't think this is a correct place for `QueryStats` interface as it is not related to loki components, but rather to what loki data source returns. I'd consider moving it to https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/main/public/app/plugins/datasource/loki/types.ts.

I'd make utility function out of this. The same way as we have `getLogQueryFromMetricsQuery` in https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/main/public/app/plugins/datasource/loki/queryUtils.ts, we could have `getStreamSelectorFromQuery`, so it could be reused in the future.

Here instead of `getBackendSrv().fetch<QueryStats>` I'd suggest to use `this.metadataRequest` in the same way as we use it to fetch labels, values, test data source connection,... . The `this.metadataRequest` uses `this.getResource` method that calls correct backend endpoint which is `/api/datasources/24/resources/...` . In your case, it is using `api/datasources/proxy/24/...` endpoint, which endpoint we migrated from, because we want all resources to be run trough `/resources`.

If you are up for it, 'd consider to add test to test this functionality - if query is changed, does the stats on the screen change? 

So you could mock `datasource.queryStatsRequest` to return some stats (you probably will need to mock it to return different values for the first and second time), and then use `rerender` to rerender the component with different query. And then check if correct (new) stats are displayed. 🙂
I would remove all of the code related to `treshold` and implement it once we know what treshold we want to use.
As mentioned before, I'd remove this code and add it back when we know what treshold are we using.

But do we need this data source check here? I'd argue that if we don't have stats, then we shouldn't render it no matter what data source. And if we have stats, then we should render it no matter what data source.

title: Explore: Add transformations to correlation data links

commits_data.message: Consolidate types, add better example, cleanup
Change ScopedVar to not require text, do not leak transformation-made variables between links
Add mappings and start implementing logfmt
Add mappings and start implementing logfmt
Remove mappings, turn off global regex
Add example yaml and omit transformations if empty
Merge branch 'main' of https://github.com/grafana/grafana into kristina/transformation
add transformation field to FE types and use it, safeStringify logfmt values
Add tests, only safe stringify if non-string, fix bug with safe stringify where it would return empty string with false value
Merge branch 'main' of https://github.com/grafana/grafana into kristina/transformation
Do not add null transformations object
Merge branch 'main' of https://github.com/grafana/grafana into kristina/transformation
Merge branch 'main' of https://github.com/grafana/grafana into kristina/transformation
Break out transformation logic, add tests to backend code
Remove unnecessary code and mark new Transformations object as internal
Add support for named capture groups
Merge branch 'main' of https://github.com/grafana/grafana into kristina/transformation

comments_data.body: Based on https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/61008#discussion_r1069309626
add omit if empty

I think global selector will not work properly with capturing, e.g.:

```
fieldValue.match(/app=(\w+)/)
(2) ['app=foo', 'foo', index: 0, input: 'app=foo host=demo-001', groups: undefined]
fieldValue.match(/app=(\w+)/g)
['app=foo']
```

In this case we need to capture "foo", not all matches of entire "app=(\w+)"
The global match was me thinking ahead on future plans where one correlation could match multiple times, like the (Batman|Superman) example. We can take out the global match for now.

Let's keep the scope of the task. We'll tackle multiple/inline links in https://github.com/grafana/grafana/issues/62056. For now let's just focus on getting simple regex transformation (no multiple group capturing) assigned to a single variable with provisioning (no UI changes). It won't be possible to easily test it with Logs Panel (we need this -> https://github.com/grafana/grafana/issues/61782), but it will be possible to test it with Table visualizations.

Considering what we've discussed in https://github.com/grafana/grafana/issues/60965 I think we may not need mappings for now. They would be handy if we had a sampler in place, but hence we start without it we assume the user needs to know name of fields so mapping will probably be redundant now.
delete
delete
Should we implement it in a cleaner way? This has the potential to grow quite a bit, maybe break the logic for transformations out to its own file?
Shouldn't this be a list of transformations?
Yes! Will update.

@ifrost Do we need to do a type assertion when the library is ambiguous about what it returns ([src](https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/blob/master/types/logfmt/index.d.ts#L42)), or is there another way?
Need to double check but I think we need to get the field from `transformation` here (it may be different than the "target field").
We will defo need it in the future and maybe move it to `feature/correlations` but we can do it later. Also you can do it now as it may make it easier to test just the transformation logic.

🤔 I think I would need to add another variable to the transformations model then. So I think what you're saying is the transformation should be applied to the transformation field (if set) or the target field (if not). That'll have to happen at a higher level to this, because this logic is only applied on the one field that's passed in - we'll want to be sure the transformation field gets it's own call. Does that sound right?

I had a quick look at https://github.com/csquared/node-logfmt/blob/master/lib/logfmt_parser.js and it seems like in some cases in may return non-string values (`true`, `false`, `null`). Maybe we can use the provided type and treat values as `object` but stringify them? (we have `safeStringifyValue` function somewhere in utils, maybe we could use that)

> because this logic is only applied on the one field that's passed in

This is the field where the link is attached to (for visualization), but we have access to all fields (via dataFrame object):

```typescript
export const getFieldLinksForExplore = (options: {
  field: Field;           // <--- where the link is displayed (used to get the config object)
  ...
  dataFrame?: DataFrame;  // <--- all the data (used to interpolate)
}):
```

It's actually currently possible to access values from other fields using `__data` variable in a link. For example you can write a query `"SELECT * FROM TABLE WHERE foo={$__data.fields.foo} AND bar={__data.fields.bar}"` such target query can be assigned to any target field.

@ifrost that makes sense. I used the same pattern as [here](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/main/public/app/features/variables/utils.ts#L65) though, where we only use this function if its a non-string - otherwise it adds quotes around a string value that we probably don't want.

One thing I noticed with `safeStringifyValue` though is that it would return an empty string with `false` instead of returning `"false"` like we would want. I changed the logic in the function - I can't imagine anyone wanting it to convert `true` but return an empty string on `false`. Seems way more likely to be a bug. Let me know what you think.
Oh right!  🤦 Thank you!

Could we call it `fieldWithLink` and the other `fieldUsedInQuery` or something like this? It's not "wrong" to use it this way, it's a valid use case, it's just that the target field and the field used in transformations can be used independently.

I'll create a separate task where we can define some clean-up subtasks, for example, we can move transformations to a separate util/file. We can do it after we add more features to actually see where different parts fit.
Could you also please update backend tests? (model validation in `models_test.go` and CRUD updates `correlations_(create/update/delete/read)_test.go`?
I meant "right" and "wrong" in terms of what the test would expect but I will be more straightforward in this naming
I split out transformations to its own file because it wasn't that difficult to do and makes sense logically, let me know if this isn't what youre thinking.
Is this `if` doing anything?
This needs to be marked as internal.
Ah no, I added it when looking at the pattern for target, but then changed it where it no longer makes sense.
opened https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/pull/64263 to get rid of this

this slightly changes the behaviour of a bunch of things, like the panel model inspector in dashboards and variables, did we test it's safe? (especially for variables as `false` and `0` would have resulted in an empty string, but `"false"` and `"0"` now, not sure if that's even possible tho)

I just couldn't imagine why we would want true to evaluate to "true" and false to evaluate to an empty string. Let's look at the usages of this function outside how it is used in this PR

- `features/dashboard/state/PanelModel.ts` - passes the entire model into this function, and that model is a required parameter. I am extremely confident that PanelModel will never evaluate to false or 0, there are a lot of required fields in it.
-  `features/variables/utils.ts` - safe-stringifies the first arg, concatenates all args together split by a space except the last one and checks that string has matches for any of the three formats for variables. I do not believe that having false or 0 evaluate to an empty string or not will have any impact on this, because the safe-stringify only runs on the first argument, and in all cases a variable reference must start with either `$` or `[` which is not possible with a false or 0 scenario.
- `features/variables/inspect/utils.ts` - Similar to the above, we safe-stringify a value and check if it matches any of the variable patterns. False or 0 or empty string will all not match. That value is not used again - it will use the matching groups instead.
- `plugins/datasource/prometheus/datasource.tsx` - This will only run if the if statement depending on the same value is true, so if the value passed in is 0 or false, it will never run in the first place

I'm very confident based on those usages that this logic will not impact anything.

title: PanelChrome: Implement hover header

commits_data.message: Match design's semantics more precisely + tweaks
Keep hover header visible when menu is open
remove extra css on the title items because they are not accessible with a keyboard
Panel Menu: Fix issue with menu positioning outside of the viewport
Panel Errors: Add back zIndex to container for headerless panels
Set hoverHeader=true if title is not present in PanelStateWrapper

HoverWidget: Remove custom offset as this is highly dependant on our
legacy core menu provider, now offset is set on PanelStateWrapper level

comments_data.body: this should be fine

I think `hasHeader` should wrapper the whole `div headerContainer`. We should take out the `statusMessage condition` out then.
Because the description, links, etc. should also show up in the hover header box, unlike:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13227501/213734904-2fee4603-8e59-422d-870c-de5ab1c4af37.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13227501/213734957-ede4df9b-9d07-4ca9-b8da-c9f4185eb1c8.png)

Imo, in general the responsibility of `PanelChrome` should not be to make calculations based on a `gridPos`. If it is used anywhere outside of a dashboard it might make no sense/use to the dev why exactly -16 px.
Maybe the `PanelStateWrapper` should calculate the y-offset and send to `PanelChrome` only a prop that references the hovering header's position directly. Something like a prop `yOffsetHoverHeader={-16}` ?

`HoverWidget` should show up directly if `hoverHeader === true`, no other conditions. 

However, if there's nothing to show (no `dragClass`, no `title`, no `description`, no `titleItems`, no `menu`, no `streaming icon if loadingState===Streaming`) then nothing should show at all.. so it seems (because it's best to avoid such a long and specific condition if each header-related item is present) that the HoverWidget might be best implemented as wrapper around some children. The children can then be set up here in the PanelChrome. It's just a thought, not certain this is best.
Not every panel by default is draggable, just if the dragClass is passed down to PanelChrome.
awesome 🙇‍♀️
Ah, I see!

```suggestion
     
```

You can safely remove this, the `TitleItem` component is adding this style, I think this was leftover after resolving conflicts :)
I agree with @polibb, if we can do these calculations in the `PanelStateWrapper` it will be better, especially when deprecating props in grafana ui is quite painful.

🤔 adding the height of 100% is making the `ToolbarButton` not preserve the 32px.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/239999/214542430-4dc97ce1-5fdc-41b9-a466-10593a19fea9.png)

I forgot to add this to the review 🙈 , here the `height: '100%',` it is also breaking the focusRing style

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/239999/214545074-6c6565de-8b5e-4f74-add5-527a58160775.mp4
yea, agree that it's probably better to just pass in a hoverHeaderOffset or something

Got confused a bit by this, but I might have missed this in design. Isn't the hover header supposed to hide all the information, and enclose it to be visible only on... hover? With empty title, but any other info (i.e. description or streaming indicator) I can still see the header:
I think menu needs some love when it comes to positioning, as now it can easily be cropped by the fold, i.e. It's not related to this PR tho, so maybe needs a fix in a separate PR :)

Yeah, that's what we were discussing today even as well because it's a bit confusing.. So, on the one hand, we want to have a separate control over whether or not the panel has a header. This would be perfect with "header yes?" _toggle_ like the one for transparency. However, this is heavily a breaking change actually and should probably be introduced in Grafana 10?
On the other hand, the current functionality is indeed that removing the title of a panel makes it to be without a header. In this sense we should indeed cover the current functionality. So imho it seems like `PanelStateWrapper` can send down to `PanelChrome` the prop `hoverHeader={true}` if there is no `title` for the panel, no other conditions (that I know of (?)).

I think we are not passing down in the `PanelStateWrapper` the `hoverHeader` prop, it should be true if  `title` is empty. It will look like this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/239999/216079032-bd1982ab-f93c-4bb4-bf04-50bacbd21fb2.png)


In the future(after the first iteration), we want to add a configurable prop in the panel to display the header on hover or not

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/239999/216079483-0d957307-a2bc-466e-87e9-74bf32a037bf.png)

You're right.. menu needs a lot of love 😺🤌. 
We were trying out some things with @axelavargas today (it is based on react-popper-tooltip), but overall part of the issue is the legacy menu that we are using with legacy positioning for a centred menu. We can have some temporary fix before the legacy is replaced with `Menu` component from `grafana/ui`, but it will be in another PR indeed.
@kaydelaney I double check and this problem still present, I think we can remove that height 100% 😄
I removed the other styling here, probably leftover from the merge. Because it helps with accessibility: https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/62466#issuecomment-1408752093
the menu doesn't receive `dragClassCancel` and can be used for dragging
Ah, right, messed that up during the merge. Thanks for spotting it!
@axelavargas pull again, I removed some merged in positioning that is preventing keyboard a11y
Can we just remove `backgroundColor` property?
If we have the container in position absolute, why do we need the `zIndex`?
I push a small commit removing it. Just trying to help with small stuff :)
I push a small commit removing it. Just trying to help with small stuff :)

Have we tried to put the hover widget on a Popover and use the dashboard as a boundary? I know it is quite complicated, so this solution is much simpler and makes it work for our case.

However, if we use the PanelChrome out of Dashboards, we will have the same problem, while if we use Poppover, we will solve it for any place where the PanelChrome is placed. I don't think this is the PR to implement this, but I'm curious if we have tried.

> However, this is heavily a breaking change actually and should probably be introduced in Grafana 10?

Not necessarily. You can implement migration that will handle that: if a panel title is empty, then you would automatically set this new hide header property to true. But of course this will require comms in release notes.
I think we need this for headerless panels 😄

~Based on the [slack](https://raintank-corp.slack.com/archives/C03MCTKAJA0/p1675330056012319) conversation, we should put back the `dragClassCancel`, the side effect of dragging and opening the menu is not ideal.~

Lol discard my message, I misunderstood the comment 😅

comments_data.body: I don't see why differentiating between `routePath` and `url`? Think `url` prop for both pages and drill-downs could be sufficient.

`from` and ` to` seem to me like sth that I would expect to be carried over automatically without a need for explicit declaration. Thinking primarily of sharing a particular entity drill-down. Once someone navigates to a particular leaf drill-down page, i.e. a log line, and shares this view via URL, then without preserving from/to, the drill-up will be broken.
Why the drill-down route is non-exact?

@dprokop well, we cannot use URL for route path for dynamic pages that have params like `/scenes/grafana-monitoring/handlers/:handler/logs`, and if we where to use a value like that we cannot use it for URL for tabs.
yes, I think this should be possible and should simplify some things

@dprokop well I can think of some edge cases, where you have a tab that should always have a specific time range. 

I am not sure what you mean by the drilldown comment, or sharing a link. preserveUrlKeys is for tabs & breadcrumbs url generation. Drilldown links generation are not handled by the SceneApp components (yet)

@dprokop to support nested routes, not exactly sure why but without it the second level routing does not work.

For example we have drilldown
```
  drilldowns: [
          {
            routePath: '/scenes/grafana-monitoring/handlers/:handler',
```

and the defines a SceneAppPage that has tabs like

```
new SceneAppPage({
        title: 'Logs',
        url: baseUrl + '/logs',
        routePath: '/scenes/grafana-monitoring/handlers/:handler/logs',
        getScene: () => getHandlerLogsScene(handler),
        preserveUrlKeys: ['from', 'to', 'var-instance'],
        drilldowns: [
          {
            routePath: '/scenes/grafana-monitoring/handlers/:handler/logs/:secondLevel',
            getPage: getSecondLevelDrilldown,
          },
        ],
```

title: Alerting: Fix QueryAndExpressionStep not using the right query

commits_data.message: Fix QueryAndExpressionStep not using the right query

comments_data.body: Did you find out the reason the `queries` variable doesn't get updated when it should? It seems we depend on it in several places so I'm worried reading it from the form values here will mask potential errors in other places.

Actually, the source of truth in here is in the `QueryEditor` component that `QueryAndExpressionStep` render as a child.

Any change done by the user is handled by the QueryEditor, and `QueryAndExpressionStep` reacts to these changes in the `onChangeQueries` method.

So, `queries` is been it's updated correctly.
The problem is that the callback passed to the `QueryEditor` contains the method that calls the `runQueries` with the queries parameter with the value we have before our `onChangeQueries` has been called.

So runQueries will be called internally by the `QueryEditor` before we update the queries in the parent component(`QueryAndExpressionStep`)
Awesome research!

Maybe check for match first make more sense?

```suggestion
			resourceCachable := resourceURLMatch && allowCacheControl(c.Resp)
```

ccHeaderValues is a string of comma separated values, so if the cache control includes a max-age this check will fail.
For example, I would expect to be able to set the following headers in the datasource resource.go:
```
 Cache-Control: private, max-age=806400
 X-Grafana-Cache: y
```
and have that pass this check.
