comments_data.body: This file should be named `dataquery.cue` instead.

We should probably define these as mandatory. I _think_ that these are optional in the frontend because it's waiting for user input to fill certain fields. This is not really necessary AFAIK. A working query should have `resources`, `metricNamespace`, `metricName`... The model should probably reflect that (and leave as optional really the fields that can be empty).
I believe all of these should be deprecated? (it's okay to leave them if you are just copying what we have in TS code).
Agreed on this, I think it's time to take the opportunity and refactor the types in Azure Monitor as a part of the schematisation 😊
Yep they're deprecated, I'll validate that they're unused and remove them (and any associated logic).

> I think that these are optional in the frontend because it's waiting for user input to fill certain fields. 

This strikes right at the heart of one of the really interesting changes inherent in moving to a schema-centric model - when it comes to defaults and optionality, we have to think about object lifecycle quite differently. i wrote a bit about it [here](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1RRPGeD7DQ7wot0Pwnc4UZolXrZYip0ViqOozl9zbBpE/edit#heading=h.fft1p4jlnh9y), but it's going to be an evolving area.

And yes in this case i agree that "waiting for frontend user input" is not a sufficient reason to mark a field as optional

If you're able to just pull these out now, awesome - i'm glad that schematization could be a forcing function to clean up some code :)

But know that as we turn on use of multi-version schemas via thema in the coming months, there will be new strategies available for handling deprecation of query types. So if trying to remove these now causes headaches when thinking about e.g. backwards compatibility, i'd say it's fine to hold off because the set of tools you have available is about to change

@spinillos could you work out a simpler repro for this buggy output and file an issue (or just a PR?)

Clearly it's an issue with our name sanitizers somewhere, i'm _guessing_ probably [here](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/3b3059c9ce94515baef5c352d07651a404102bfc/pkg/plugins/plugindef/plugindef.go#L43). The right place to put a test case would be [in here](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/3b3059c9ce94515baef5c352d07651a404102bfc/pkg/plugins/pfs/pfs_test.go#L16)

Its because cfg.RootName contains spaces. I checked this sanitizer and it doesn't looks like that its causing this issue.

I fixed like this: https://github.com/grafana/thema/pull/104 but idk if its the correct place to do it.
Underlying issue here was fixed in #62144 - merging main and rerunning `make gen-cue` should fix it.

@sdboyer this is what I meant (sorry if my explanation was a bit confusing). This `DimensionFilters` struct is defined above on line 155 as `AzureMetricDimension` so I would expect it to be referenced here but instead the whole `AzureMetricDimension` struct is duplicated.

Sorry, yes, this is the flipside of the thing i was describing, but i put it poorly.

These should clearly just be a reference to the other generated type. But they're getting _incorrectly inlined_ right now because of the config option we have to set in order to _correctly inline_ `DataQuery` itself.

It's a bug, and we'll fix it 😄 

(also ughhh we've got slice pointers again! @spinillos )
being strictly these definitions are frontend-only so in theory we don't need to define them in CUE schemas. Is there any oficial position for this kind of definitions?
it'd be nice to have some pretiffier here, the indentation and spaces can be a bit arbitrary
I'm not sure there is at the moment, I've defined these temporarily but with the aim of removing as many of them as possible 😊 Phase 2 of the Azure schema work is to massively clean up the types 😜
Apparently there's `make fix-cue` command you can run.

```suggestion
  { label: 'Time series', value: ResultFormat.TimeSeries },
```
Could this use a more consistent naming?
This doesn't seem to do anything for me. Afaict this is the formatted version :/
Can we also document that it's a workaround until the type extensions in cue are fixed? A TODO comment would be great, so we remember to fix it later.

```suggestion
						#ResultFormat: "table" | "time_series" @cuetsy(kind="enum",memberNames="Table|TimeSeries")
```
Looks like we need to provide the member names as the ones with underscores (also dashes) aren't properly formatted.
So the actual data source query generated from schema is not used?
Yeah, seems like it disregards tabs vs spaces distinction :(
I can use the type, however for the sake of readable code the name `AzureMonitor` doesn't make sense. This name should be `AzureMonitorQuery` but I can't tell how to rename the default.
Yes I'll make sure to do this!
Yep I'll have a look at this
@sdboyer shouldn't data query names indeed end in "Query"?

title: Alerting: Fix recording rules showing alert notification information.

commits_data.message: Fix recording rules form steps not showing alert information
Fix docs about creating cloud and recording rules

comments_data.body:
```suggestion
1. In Step 1, add the rule name. The recording rule name must be a valid metric name.
```
What does "must be a valid metric name" mean? could we maybe write this more clearly?

```suggestion
   - Add custom labels selecting existing key-value pairs from the drop down, or add new labels by entering the new key or value.
1. Click **Save** to save the recording rule or **Save and exit** to save the recording rule and go back to the Alerting page.
```

```suggestion
1. In Step 3, add evaluation behavior.
   - Enter a valid **For** duration. The expression has to be true for this long for the alert to be fired.
```
means that Recording rule names must also be valid prometheus metric names, that is, contain no whitespace. Maybe we could add this requirement 👍

```suggestion
1. In Step 1, add the rule name. The recording name must be a Prometheus metric name and contain no whitespace.
```

title: [API Split] Move star api inside of packages

commits_data.message: move star api inside of packages

comments_data.body: I think at this point we should be able to remove star.Service as a dependency of the HTTP Server, since star.API injects that on its own.
It would be nice to remove `routing.Wrap` as part of such PRs and use plain old http handlers instead
search and navtree are still using star.Service as dependency. we probably need to keep it for now.

title: Preferences: Add theme preference to match system theme

commits_data.message:
Apply suggestions from code review

Co-authored-by: Christopher Moyer <35463610+chri2547@users.noreply.github.com>

comments_data.body:
```suggestion
Sets the default UI theme: `dark`, `light`, or `system`. The default theme is `dark`.
```

```suggestion
`system` matches the user's system theme.
```
It feels strange that we are deprecating it and then adding it again on a new `interface`, but I guess that's right?
We should leave this as `lightName`
Do we want to leave this with 'dark' as default?

title: Plugins: Add backend target to instrumentation
Alerting: Support context.Context in Loki interface

commits_data.message:
Alerting: Support context.Context in Loki interface

This commit adds support for canceleable contexts in the Loki
interface.
Add cancelation deadline and context initCtx

comments_data.body: You might want a timeout here, but I'm not sure what value you would like?
Isn't there already a timeout at the client level?
There is a default 30 seconds timeouts for `loki_http`, but I was thinking you might want a timeout here that is potentially shorter, or at least consistent across all pluggable backends.
There is, `30s`.

I would definitely recommend we use a timeout of some sort for the context because then cancelation can be used for any additional additional work done by a pluggable backend, not just the HTTP request.

Let's make the call - can we please also create a context with a 10 second timeout for this?

Let's go with shorter than 30s, this isn't pushing any data to loki, it's just a ping basically.

title: CommandPalette: Design tweaks and design fixes

commits_data.message: Fix gradient border pos issue, and heading padding

comments_data.body:
is this intentional? leaves a gap on the LHS

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20999846/214318321-5d3568e4-3d7a-4f90-a039-dca098fd9d18.png)

what do you think about `md` here? fits most titles pretty comfortably and doesn't have as much empty space

| `lg` | `md` |
| --- | --- |
| ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20999846/214319571-7f770e46-f6c5-4905-ab88-5211f4d5cac0.png) | ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20999846/214319751-cad58b96-46f1-4e37-960b-3ad068bb3e58.png) |
do you think we'll have any issues with this being different to the top search bar placeholder now, or should we try to keep them the same? 🤔
I like the `md` version better personally.
@ashharrison90 I was thinking we change the placeholder text of global search input to match
Agree for the medium width. I think the large just the modal too wide and mostly empty.

I don't think this is needed (or looks good). I think it's weird that items are clipped before the bottom of the modal 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/46142/214391570-95902bc2-f90b-465a-86d5-474de4cc068f.png)

As the code is now, this comment is no longer accurate and should be removed.

However, I think that section headers need additional 8px above them to separate them from the previous section and prevent the hover background from being flush against the border:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/46142/214395119-7a8762ff-c96b-4724-bdb4-2ca9f51ce080.png)

Additionally, I think that there should be ~8px _less_ padding _under_ section headers - i think the section header is too far away from it's items.

more noticable to me on light theme - looks like a bug

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/46142/214395526-2bdfbf40-6d73-4d6c-bcee-7c57d99692f4.png)
ah, stupid me I see the bug your talking about now.

I think it depends on how we add folders and tags. There are really long folder and dashboard names, and dashboards with many tags. I think an md modal will get really ugly with wrapping or cut text and tags. 

But I can leave it md for now. but pretty sure we need to extend it if we want this to take the role of global search
Pages don't have 8px padding at the bottom of the window that clips before the edge of the screen. I see this as being the same.
@joshhunt that's a good argument, I am fine with removing it. 👍

comments_data.body: I dont think the oss grafana server should depend on an enterprise service. Is this temporary?
are we talking about datasource caching or query caching here?

It's not relying on an enterprise service per se, it just needs an implementation of the interface, and that impl is OSS or Enterprise depending on the build. I believe this is the Grafana convention for this sort of thing.
This is talking about query caching, specifically the cache config per datasource
cool, that makes sense 👍
I'll run it by the backend platform squad just to be sure though
Would suggest putting these changes in Enterprise using the `hooksService.AddIndexDataHook` method. Can get rid of some additional code/services
Shouldn't this be the default when no TTL configured/set? Is it really needed?
I would put whether this is enabled or not on `PluginMetaQueryOptions` to follow the existing convention.

## Overly permissive regular expression range

Suspicious character range that overlaps with \w in the same character class.

looking at the tests, the purpose of this regexp it to somehow clean another regexp string? but it's only replacing a single opening brace followed by alphanum plus a bunch of other chars?

comments_data.body: I am not sure that at this moment we can just say it's no longer apache license as we mostly just moved it. I mean this would change the license to AGPL-3 and not sure if Apache license permits that (mind that as it's not all our code we cannot relicense it if license does not permit it I think)

i was wondering the same, according to https://www.apache.org/foundation/license-faq.html#Distribute-changes

>I'VE MADE IMPROVEMENTS TO THE APACHE CODE; MAY I DISTRIBUTE THE MODIFIED RESULT?
Absolutely -- subject to the [terms of the Apache license](https://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0#redistribution), of course. You can give your modified code away for free, sell it, keep it to yourself, or whatever you like. Just remember that the original code is still covered by the Apache license and you must comply with its terms. Even if you change every single line of the Apache code you're using, the result is still based on the Foundation's licensed code. You may distribute the result under a different license, but you need to acknowledge the use of the Foundation's software. To do otherwise would be stealing.
If you think others would find your changes useful, though, we do encourage you to submit them to the appropriate Apache project for possible inclusion.

and the [terms](https://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0#redistribution) makes it look quite clear to me that we can't just relicense it 🤔
Are you planning to fix typing in upcoming PR/s? Do you have a task in the backlog to address it?

Thank you for noticing this! In my rush to remove everything "jaeger-ui" related I didn't notice that I was removing the license. I re-added the `LICENSE_APACHE2` file to the new directory and updated `LICENSING.md` to list the new directory as licensed under Apache2.

Good point @ifrost. We planned a few changes to the Trace View for the next few months and some of these files are bound to suffer a lot of changes, I'll take a note to attempt to remove usages of `any` wherever possible.
FWIW we should probably just remove `eslint-disable @typescript-eslint/no-explicit-any` and add an entry to betterer results instead, so they'll be tracked with all others `any` usage
Agreed, just committed those changes!

title: Docs: Update expression documentation to mention no data

commits_data.message: update expression documentation to mention no data

comments_data.body:
> When data source returns no data points the expression engine produces special result `NoData`.

I think it might be more accurate to say "no data items", or perhaps "no series or numbers", as there could be a Series with no datapoints in it, and I don't think this gets classified as "No Data".

Ref: https://github.com/grafana/grafana-plugin-sdk-go/tree/main/data/contract_docs#no-data-and-empty

```suggestion
When any queried data source returns no series or numbers, the expression engine returns `NoData`.  For example, if a request contains two data source queries that are merged by an expression, if `NoData` is returned by at least one of the data source queries, then the returned result for the entire query is `NoData`.
```

```suggestion
For more information about how [Grafana Alerting]({{< relref "../../../alerting/" >}}) processes `NoData` results, refer to [No data and error handling]({{< relref "../../../alerting/alerting-rules/create-grafana-managed-rule/#no-data-and-error-handling" >}}).
```

comments_data.body:
This seems to me like a bit weird structuring. The `getMetadata` does not seem to be doing anything super expensive and seems like it needs the things that would make this component rerender anyway so this seems like premature optimization and probably does not give you much. It would be easier to just use `getMetadata` directly in the render function and compute on every render IMHO.

At the same time though the `getMetadata` is already defined in the `<FlameGraphMetadata>` component. Why aren't all the dependencies here just props for the `FlameGraphMetadata` component and the computation done just there? Less things get exported and it would be easy to just add `React.memo` and memorize the component if that needed some perf optimization.
Thanks.. I've pushed the changes.

title: Alerting: Allow separate read and write path URLs for Loki state history

commits_data.message: Extract config parsing and add tests

comments_data.body:
Is there any reason why we return the default value instead of a nil? I'm not hugely opinionated either way, but I think this way is perhaps less common in Grafana?

```suggestion
func NewLokiConfig(cfg setting.UnifiedAlertingStateHistorySettings) (*LokiConfig, error) {
```
I'm opinionated, and we should stop using Pointer Types everywhere.

I've seen this pattern be used for structs in a number of places - the idiom is usually to return the default of the type, not necessarily nil (which only happens to be nil, for pointer types).

Specifically, I chose this because it doesn't make sense for anything to accept a nil LokiConfig anywhere, so I didn't want to introduce nullability into the type when constructing it.
The reason I ask is `(*Type, error)` occurs frequently in the stdlib, `(Type, error)` not so much. For example, `http.NewRequest` and `url.Parse`.

title: Alerting: Allow pausing alerts from provisioning

commits_data.message: Add IsPaused to provision export endpoints
Add exception for reset state in first loop iteration of scheduler if rule is paused
Update provision definition and swagger docs
Add more context to a comment

comments_data.body: There should also be a change in this function, right now this makes it so the provisioning API can read whether a rule is paused, but the field will not be mapped (and remain false) if something tries to set the paused flag through the prov API.
Let's make the example `false` for the docs purposes, as a typical rule is not paused
Can this be simplified to `currentRuleVersion > 0 || isPaused`?
If a brand new paused rule is file-provisioned (i.e. currentRuleVersion == 0 and isPaused = true), would there be any existing state to begin with? What gets cleaned up?

In that particular case you mention, it won't have any state to clean up but imagine this scenario:
- Have one provisioned alert rule with, at least, one alert instance.
- We update the provisioning file to pause that alert and restart Grafana for these changes to take effect (we must have a DB that lives between restarts for this to happen)

If we don't do this change the previous-restart alert instance from the currently paused alert will linger forever for the user to see until the alert rule is updated (stale states are cleaned up in `ProcessEvalResults` which we skip when an alert is paused).

IMO, a single useless state cleanup is a better price to pay than a forever lingering useless alert instance.

comments_data.body: Is there a specific reason we need to change width here? I _think_ we can leave it as it was. The variable holds the width of the panel and is unrelated to the width of the table itself, which will fit into the panel and the overflow will be scrollable.

I'm wondering whether we can avoid using `cloneDeep` in here since it could be quite expensive in some cases. Could we not just form a new array for the map below in a different way? Maybe something like `[ fieldToAdd, ...filterFields]`?
Do we really need more than just a shallow copy here?
Again, I think we should avoid cloneDeep. I think a shallow copy would be okay
I think this should be reverted
I think this should also be reverted

Think this should also be reverted.

Looking through it though, I realised there are a lot of improvements I could do here for the count rows stuff. Like here, for example, this entire if-clause could be moved before the `getFooterItems` call and return if count rows is set. We don't necessarily need `footerItems.length`
Yep, without it, the table won't flex to the proper width when the row number column is not being rendered.
I think this needs to be reverted. It is failing the CI build
skipped. but I would like to know why this kills the build...

I assume the duration of loading some table under some circumstances detailed in the test is larger than the expected value and thus it fails:

```
FAIL packages/grafana-ui/src/components/Table/utils.test.tsx (6.321 s)
  ● Table utils › sortNumber › should have good performance

    expect(received).toBeLessThanOrEqual(expected)

    Expected: <= 20
    Received:    53.36573200020939

      516 |       const stop = performance.now();
      517 |       const diff = stop - start;
    > 518 |       expect(diff).toBeLessThanOrEqual(20);
          |                    ^
```

I believe I needed to do this because when we use the setHiddenColumns() hook from React Table - which I use to show/hide the table number row - the table calculations don't automatically account for the new table width and flex accordingly. Which is why when we hide the row, we see this empty space: This calculation was meant to deal with that.
So when the number row is hidden, we need to add back the width of that hidden row.

title: SplitOpen: Update API to accept multiple queries

commits_data.message: SplitOpen: Update API to accept multiple queries
Explore: Deprecate query in SplitOpenOptions and add queries

comments_data.body:
Could we change it to?

```suggestion
  queries: T[];
```

I don't think it's truly public API 🤔 This function is passed only within Explore to visualizations (which are only internal). So I guess we could just change the type `query -> queries`. We can also mark `query` as deprecated and remove in G10
It is also used in `SplitOpen` which is used in `dataLinks` in `packages/grafana-data/src/utils/dataLinks.ts` which is used in `getFieldLinksForExplore` which is used across many panels.
Which again, we could update, but I am just saying that because it is part of public API, we are not sure if it is not used somewhere else.

So I am happy to do whatever Explore team is the best, but personally I thought this is the best and it doesn't require deprecations, changing of optional parameter to required along the way, breaking changes, .... 🙂
tbh i feel like @ivanahuckova solution is a bit more robust. i'm also not a big fan of having `query` accept multiple types, but given the way we expose it it feels the safest approach
I'd prefer to do more work and have cleaner API in the future. We choose to do it not because it's easy, but because it's hard :D

So just to confirm, the preffered solution would be:
1. add `queries?: T[]` type
2. deprecate `queries?: T` and make it optional and let users know they should use queries
3. Internally use `queries` instead of `query` everywhere
4. In Grafana 10, remove `query?` and add breaking change

Does that sound right? @ifrost

Sounds good!

I guess you meant:

> deprecate queries?: T

deprecate `query?: T`
yes!
https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/62245/files
I sneaked this in as this is the place where we want to pass more queries and reason for this PR. 😇
*old man yelling at clouds* 😂

Azure Monitor: Allow multi-value variables

comments_data.body:
This is the main limitation of the feature. For getting things like metric names, we need a valid combination of resource group + resource name. Since we are just getting the first combination possible, it may be wrong.

This is usually fine since template variables are ordered, meaning that resource names for the first resource group will be listed first but it's brittle.

An alternative would be to rather than just using the first possible query when getting things like metric names, use all of them. That means that we would do several queries that return a 404 but some requests will return valid values.

None of the options are great so I am sticking to this one since it's more simple.

title: Alerting: Add endpoint for querying state history

comments_data.body:
We aren't checking any flags, and instead just registering this endpoint straight up.

It doesn't need to wait on the Loki work to be completed. It works just fine for annotations too, you get a dataframe containing the annotation data. When using annotations, some query parameters are not supported, but you'll still get something back.

Open to feedback on this URI, but there were a few careful considerations here:

- It felt cleaner to hang this off the ruler endpoint, as it's logically asking about what happened inside the ruler, in the past.
- `/api/ruler/grafana/states/history` Implies the existence of `/api/ruler/grafana/states` for non-historical states, which we aren't planning on adding.
- An rpc-style `POST .../query-states` or `POST ../query-history` makes creating the label queries easier, but it's not quite as idiomatic.

nit:

I'd object on point 1 - I don't think this is necessarily part of the "ruler" and we have precedent on putting things that relate to rules/alerts under `api/v1/rule` (see backtest, rules testing and eval).

For this, my suggestion would be `api/v1/rule/history`
I'd expect this to be needed on all cases.

I avoided this approach because the resource hierarchy of `rule/history` implies that's the history for an individual rule resource. But, the endpoint doesn't work like this - you can also issue queries across all the rules.

I'd be more OK with a slight modification - `rules/history`?

My other concern, is that we also have the concept of versioned rule _definitions_ - `rule/history` at a glance suggests that it's returning all the past versions of this rule's definition, not the history of its evaluations.

`rules/evaluations/history` perhaps? If there's precedent for `rule`, we can go with that, but the `evaluations/history` is more clear IMO.

That's a good point - I'm fine with `rules/history`  - I don't think `evaluation` adds anything. IMO `versions` as part of an API Is a common idiom and I would expect something related to versions of a rule to have this keyword in its path as opposed to history but can see the argument.
Good point, I'll drop the comment, there is only one fully fleshed out backend anyway so it's not relevant anyway.

Done! I admit it feels a bit weird not adding this to `/rule/` - my only issue there, is that everything under `/rule/` today is actually just the testing API, and this isn't logically associated with that at all. Maybe those could be moved to `/api/v1/testing/...` at some point?

We could even just do `/api/v1/state-history` which is super safe, and not attached to anything. It's just one endpoint though. :shrug:

title: Alerting: Improve comments on alert table migration immutability

commits_data.message: Alerting: Improve comments around alert migration immutability

comments_data.body: :tada: Nice!

Thoughts on just combining this func with `historicalTablesMigrations` and having one big non-frozen func containing everything that we append to?

Alternatively, this one could go in `historicalTablesMigrations` - This one is kind of paired logically with `addAlertmanagerConfigHistoryMigrations(mg)` so IMO they should live next to each other, wherever they go.

Yeah, good idea, `ualert.go` was not the best place.

Not for this PR, but I'm just curious - WDYT about eventually having one file for each non-trivial migration? The legacy->UA migration could be its own subpackage, etc. Or is that overkill?
The intention was to use the latest one as a sort of example to follow, but I agree it should be alongside `addAlertmanagerConfigHistoryMigrations`. I'll move it into `historicalTablesMigrations`

I think it still wouldn't solve the underlying issue. IMO, the confusion is mostly caused by the fact that our main legacy -> new alerting migration isn't really a migration:

- It's mutable. It changes quite often.
- It's reversible. This means, it needs to be constantly updated to work with the most recent data model otherwise there can be issues if the the migration is reverted and reapplied.
- It's optional. So, knowing it was applied gives us no information on what their migrated alerts look like now since it depends entirely on the version they did the migration and if they have since modified them.
- Because of the above, it can't be composed in a way to apply step-wise over time; the migration is all or nothing. This means that if someone has previously migrated in, say 8.4, they would have to revert and remigrate to take advantage of any improvements since then.

These migration assumptions more closely resemble an 'upgrade tool/cli' and if I were to recommend making large changes to it now that's probably what I would go for. Basically, extract the legacy migration that actually converts their alerting data as a tool and keep the other migrations (such as table schemas) as ones that are immutable and can be reasoned around like any other migration in Grafana.

This won't change any of the points from above. We'd still have to maintain the tool to upgrade to the current data model. But, it would mean our actual migrations can be reasoned around more clearly.

title: Alerting: Fix Test Receivers when settings are non-strings

commits_data.message:
Alerting: Fix Test Receivers when settings are non-strings

As part of the Alerting extraction, we want to make sure we don't have circular depedencies. As such, I had to move `PostableGrafanaReceiver` to a new struct in `grafana/alerting` called `GrafanaReceiver`.

`PostableGrafanaReceiver` has an attribute called `Settings` that uses a Grafana-propietary struct called `RawMessage`, this struct shadows `json.RawMessage`.

When I created `GrafanaReceiver`, I turned settings into a `map[string]string` thinking all settings would end up as strings. This was a mistake, and this test proves that it doesn't work, and breaks the API.
Track the right commit of main

InfluxDB: Send retention policy with InfluxQL queries if its been specified.

commits_data.message:
InfluxDB: Send retention policy with InfluQL queries if it's been specified.

In InfluxDB v2, due to technical limitations of the InfluxDB v1
compatibility layer, retention policies in a query (e.g. "<retention
policy>.<measurement_name>") aren't honored and must be specified in the
URL query parameter `rp` to be applied. Grafana doesn't send this query
parameter which results in all queries resolving to the default
retention policy when querying InfluxDB v2 servers using InfluxQL.

This addresses the issue by sending the `rp` query parameter for queries
that have specified a retention policy in the `target` given to
`runExploreQuery`.

The outcomes are:

1. InfluxQL queries executed against InfluxDB v2 databases will have the
   necessary retention policy information for queries like `SHOW FIELD
   KEYS FROM measurement` to function correctly.
2. InfluxQL queries executed against InfluxDB v1 databases will be
   unaffected, because this `rp` query parameter is unsupported there.

You can read more about the rentention policy mapping behavior of
InfluxDB v2 in our documentation:

- https://docs.influxdata.com/influxdb/v2.6/reference/api/influxdb-1x/dbrp/#when-querying-data
- https://docs.influxdata.com/influxdb/v2.6/reference/api/influxdb-1x/query/#query-a-non-default-retention-policy

Use the ? operator

Co-authored-by: Ryan McKinley <ryantxu@gmail.com>

@Clarity-89 What about generated type for `BasePipelineMetricAggregation` that produce invalid/incorrect types: 

```
Interface 'BasePipelineMetricAggregation' incorrectly extends interface 'MetricAggregationWithField'.

```

Not sure why this is happening and where `type: string` is coming from, because it should be `type: PipelineMetricAggregationType`. And even if it was over-ruled in `BasePipelineMetricAggregation` and then  by `BaseMetricAggregation` that again extends it, the type should be `type: MetricAggregationType;` where `MetricAggregationType` can be `PipelineMetricAggregationType`. @Clarity-89 @sdboyer Also any idea/help on how to define these?
Looking at the CI errors, you probably also need to do smth like `export { Elasticsearch as ElasticsearchQuery} from './dataquery.gen'`.

```suggestion
import {
  BucketAggregationType,
  Filter,
  MetricAggregation,
  MetricAggregationType,
  MovingAverageEWMAModelSettings,
  MovingAverageHoltModelSettings,
  MovingAverageHoltWintersModelSettings,
  MovingAverageLinearModelSettings,
  MovingAverageModel,
  MovingAverageSimpleModelSettings,
  PipelineMetricAggregationType,
  TermsOrder,
} from './dataquery.gen';

export * from './dataquery.gen';
export { Elasticsearch as ElasticsearchQuery } from './dataquery.gen';
```

I think you can do this instead, the explicitly defined types will override the `*` import and the rest won't need to be declared explicitly.

comments_data.body:
so if we do this, it should at least make the Go types compile, because we won't have an issue with the prefix dropper getting rid of `Dashboard` anymore.

If you do this, then you can hackily re-export it from the [common veneer](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/3006a457f2ca62369149fb24de02c757bb6bec9a/packages/grafana-schema/src/veneer/common.types.ts#L1). Then, when we're able to move these out of the dashboard kind and into the commons, there won't be an issue with package name conflicts anymore.
Are we planning to solve this name dropping? Maybe we can avoid it with a custom tag. It will create inconsistencies if we use veneers for renaming. Anyways, I think it is good for now :)

> Are we planning to solve this name dropping? Maybe we can avoid it with a custom tag. It will create inconsistencies if we use veneers for renaming. Anyways, I think it is good for now :)

We cannot use Veneers for renaming, because when regenerating `index.gen.ts`, the export is generated with the schema name (it makes total sense). How can we solve this without exporting "Dash" prefixed variables?

> We cannot use Veneers for renaming, because when regenerating index.gen.ts, the export is generated with the schema name (it makes total sense). 

What if you drop `@grafana(TSVeneer="type")` for this variable and add the veneer manually? So in `dashboard.types` you do `import { DashVariableModel as DashboardVariableModel }` and re-export it, could it work?
I don't understand what OrgSystemVariableModel, DashSystemVariableModel and UserSystemVariableModel are doing here they are never persisted, just runtime "macros"

What is the error here?  would it get saved in dashboard json?

is there anything better than `any ` we can use?  (i know that is our current model)
A variable with no options can be an empty object. See https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/64358
Yes, they should be living in `@grafana/data` only. I didn't realize they are runtime only. Thanks Torkel
This line is duplicated. I don't understand why it doesn't complain...

Its overriding `type` value from `#BaseVariableModel`. This value is defined as `#VariableType`, so the correct way to override should be `#VariableType & "custom"`. It should be update for all other models.
